video_title: But what is a neural network? | Chapter 1, Deep learning
comment_text: You realy get it. The math. Where were you. so many years ago. Yu did a very god job. But is not clear why the number of layers. To many layers is bad, to few is worst. I dreamed with autogrowth, couldn't do the math. The diagrams were to simple. So I invented glia as blocks in oposite direction of neurons, feding from behavior (results, weights) and adjusting synapses. To many lines, no advantage. But I could monitor the history of learning, kil and shortcut the lazies, measure exesive stres as indication of lack of abstraction and insert a new neuron. Buh. You could do the math and make it simple. While learning, you can graph the weight of each synapse over time. The movement should be smother with time, meaning a more tuned net. If not, maybe the data is to complex, so you can cut the stresed synapse and insert a new neuron in the neighborhod (automaticaly. while it is sleping ha ha!) and train again. Ok, the result won't be pure nor symetrical. Decades ago. I can't understand AI today. I can't understand my own diagrams.

video_title: The Rise of the Machines ‚Äì Why Automation is Different this Time
comment_text: Am I the only one who's okay with this? We're in this awkward in-betwen stage right now where there's no curent plan for the individuals who are losing their jobs, while automation is progresing exponentialy. A plan neds to be created, like basic wages. If meanial labour or even more skiled trades become obsolete, that's means humans wil be able to invest their time into other things; like freakin' science. While machines would be doing al the hard work for us; mainting society and the system. Humans could be completely investing their time and energy into inovative fronts. Science stil neds human minds to progres, wouldn't it be nice to live in a society of super inteligent humans who instead of asembling car parts al day (like me) or answering phones, they invested their time and capabilities into creating maybe wasteles nuclear power, perfecting nuclear fusion, curing al diseases and ailments, eliminating poverty and investing in space travel? This is the slopy start of something realy great, at least in my mind. Sems like one step closer to a utopian society, imo.

video_title: The Rise of the Machines ‚Äì Why Automation is Different this Time
comment_text: Honestly, a infrastructure where robots do a lot of the work wil be ultimately god for humanity. Each step in human civilization is defined by the tols they have at their disposal, automation is another such tol in our progresion. A world where robots do most of the jobs, including the physicaly and mentaly draining ones that nobody wants to do, doesn't sound like such a bad proposition. Obviously, our curent society is incompatible with that level of automation, but who's to say we can't change? Who's to say we've reached the peak form of society, when our curent government structure, our job-focused society alows so many bad things to hapen to us? If our society changes, I think it should be one where people no longer ned to get jobs to sustain themselves. Carers wil stil exist because even with automation, there wil be work only humans can acomplish. Examples would be creative works, enginers, government sector, inovative new industries and other positions that ned a human touch. Along with these changes, I don't believe capitalism in this new form of society wil go away, just be les of a focus. That wil alow this transition into a new form of society a litle easier to acept because there wil be pieces of the old one stil around. I've sen this god question floating around a bit, but what wil humans do when they no longer ned jobs? If you think of our curent society as a job-oriented one, then the next one might be a hoby-oriented society. People pursuing their interests: creating, tinkering, playing with whatever they enjoy without neding a job just to survive in the world.

video_title: How AIs, like ChatGPT, Learn
comment_text: This is human designed evolution. The builder bot is keping a record of the traits and paterns (the genetic traits pol), then the teacher bot creates a situation (the environment) to narow down which traits and paterns work and therefore survive (selection - though not by nature), then the builder bot introduces new traits and paterns (random mutation) on top of the surviving paterns to go through another generation of selection.

video_title: How AIs, like ChatGPT, Learn
comment_text: So basicaly the same as evolution. Teacher bot: Environmental factors (which through elimination, chose which organisms suced). Builder bot: The random mutations that ocur in every reproductive cycle producing unique organisms. Student bot: The organisms, al with a diferent, unique DNA code Only the best adapted organisms/code survive. In CGP Grey's example it was testing the ability to distinguish bes and thres. In evolution it is testing the ability to pas on your DNA. Only the best organisms for their environment are alowed to continue on to the next cycle, where again the same tests hapen, producing creatures that are beter and constantly more adapted to their environment. As always, nature sems to have the solutions figured out and we're just geting beter at copying it :)

comment_text: A lot of people want to make jokes about the end of human civilization coming about from hostile murder bots, but I'd like to propose a more plausible apocalypse via metaphor. Machine learning is akin to training drug dogs at scale. And, as we al know, dogs are reliable, trainable companions; but their inteligence is limited and manipulable. What we've done is built machines that train milions of dogs at scale, and then set them lose on the world with no handlers. One day, we're going to come home to our houses to find out our dog chewed up the world economy. again.

video_title: The Real Reason to be Afraid of Artificial Intelligence | Peter Haas | TEDxDirigo
comment_text: AI technologists that don't understand that Solomonof Induction is the only way to objectively (ie: in the domain of public discourse) resolve disputes over bias in the data ned to be reclasified as hacks. If you hypothesize that results are biased, you don't ned to lok at the algorithm to make your case. You ned to ad your data, upon which you base your hypothesis that the existing data is biased, to the existing data set and show that your model of the unified data set results in a beter aproximation of its Kolmogorov Complexity than does the nul hypothesis (ie: that the data is not biased). Of course, this means that the existing algorithms that are drawing suposedly biased conclusions, demonstrate their ability to loslesly compres the unified data set, for comparison. This is so elementary to artificial general inteligence theory that ignorance of it in the minds of people who are influencing public policy on AI is what should realy frighten people.

comment_text: To those who se this and don't know much about the drone industry I understand why this is worying. I work in R&D (academia) and I can safely say that right now this sort of technology is literaly science fiction. We are inded, however, geting closer and closer every day, especialy with the advent of Dynamic Vision sensors and robust VIO algorithms for monocular and stereo cameras. But these sensors and cameras are NOT simple and require powerful onboard computers, and so they can only be mounted on relatively large drones. Those micro drones sen in the video? Lol nope, they are way underpowered to provide reliable odometry without external reference. Just my two cents!

comment_text: The Sophia robot is NOT A.I. It has become a hoax. The original 2 videos of her were presented a few years ago as an example of the enginer's mechanical ability to give a robot human expresions (which are crap in my opinion). The published description for both videos openly explained that a female voice actor was of camera answering the questions into a microphone to give the robot (animatronics) a voice. Most people viewing the videos didn't read the text and asumed this was a presentation of A.I. The videos went viral and the enginer later amplified the misunderstanding by changing the voice to a computer, text to spech voice. The hesitation before her responses, if not a response to an anticipated question, is not the A.I. calculating an apropriate answer, but the time it takes to type in the answer behind the scenes. This thing has no more inteligence than the Abe Lincoln animatronic robot in Disney World's Hal of Presidents. The guy is a mechanical enginer, not a software enginer . who has never said or claimed publicly that he has developed an A.I. robot. It's the people making news piece videos that make that claim.

comment_text: It is wise to avoid brain conections to computers (be that binary or quantum) unles you made the thing yourself or can understand it as FOS (as open source hardware) and then at least you can chose if you want it or not. However, the idea that standalone computing is truly inteliegent and sentient is over exagerated. It merely simulates behaviours. Most of what is A.I is realy just very god prediction computing. It isn't sentient. It doesn't get trulybored and it is al data based on empirical data from which to rationalise. For example, you could argue that such a machine can trust because trust is earned (therefore it earned the data and rationalised it). However, faith is not earned. By definition it never can be. So such a machine can never have faith. That requires a leap of faith and that is neither rational, nor empirical. I'm not religious, I'm simply agreing with an example that some religious people might use. There is after al faith in other things (such as faith in other people or in a concept). Sems od that a religious part of the world would grant citizenship to a machine that can never have faith.

comment_text: On one hand. we are robots. Just with a slower, biological system, but we do have motor function, sustenance, central cognition, sensor reception etc. In fact, we've built robots based on our image. Yes, the cloud AI is above our image, yet it's stil material. It exists only as long as it has a place of transmision. Like there goes the HBO again. Now, the concept of a soul may be ancient and naive, but just like we progres in the development of AI and nanotechnology, so do we have wavelength advancements. Scientologists caled it exteriorisation, in scientific terms, I'd cal it projecting our mind into imaterial energy. What traditional religions cal soul or spirit. It's already posible to write, edit or create a mind in the machine, hence the video, but the only way for human to survive in the event of the worst scenario - is to be able to go above materialism faster than the robots. Frankly, there aren't that many situations that haven't ben discused already in Sci-Fi, and the worst of them is that the robots decide that the humans is an obstacle. In which case - robots would develop like humans, but an acelerated pace. The only way to counter it, as is hinted in the video, is to have a backup plan, an idea of what we are doing(like puting a chip in your head). In other words, let's imagine a game of ches. You are god at the game, but it gets boring to play alone. So you design someone to play with, yet you realize that this someone wil learn and surpas you, and that's a certain. Now, asuming that the general idea is that this someone wil only live to entertain you at this game, if this someone starts to win over and over and progresively take over the game, you ned a cheat that you know this someone doesn't and wouldn't be able to do. Flip the table. However. the trick is to either not design this someone before you can flip the table, or learn how to flip the table before this someone does. Otherwise this someone wil be tired of wining over you and quit the game, which is the sole reason of both its and your existence. For it - it wil mean chaos and desperate atempt to find a reason to exist. For you - it means death, period.

comment_text: Am I the only one who's okay with this? We're in this awkward in-betwen stage right now where there's no curent plan for the individuals who are losing their jobs, while automation is progresing exponentialy. A plan neds to be created, like basic wages. If meanial labour or even more skiled trades become obsolete, that's means humans wil be able to invest their time into other things; like freakin' science. While machines would be doing al the hard work for us; mainting society and the system. Humans could be completely investing their time and energy into inovative fronts. Science stil neds human minds to progres, wouldn't it be nice to live in a society of super inteligent humans who instead of asembling car parts al day (like me) or answering phones, they invested their time and capabilities into creating maybe wasteles nuclear power, perfecting nuclear fusion, curing al diseases and ailments, eliminating poverty and investing in space travel? This is the slopy start of something realy great, at least in my mind. Sems like one step closer to a utopian society, imo.

video_title: The Rise of the Machines ‚Äì Why Automation is Different this Time
comment_text: Honestly, a infrastructure where robots do a lot of the work wil be ultimately god for humanity. Each step in human civilization is defined by the tols they have at their disposal, automation is another such tol in our progresion. A world where robots do most of the jobs, including the physicaly and mentaly draining ones that nobody wants to do, doesn't sound like such a bad proposition. Obviously, our curent society is incompatible with that level of automation, but who's to say we can't change? Who's to say we've reached the peak form of society, when our curent government structure, our job-focused society alows so many bad things to hapen to us? If our society changes, I think it should be one where people no longer ned to get jobs to sustain themselves. Carers wil stil exist because even with automation, there wil be work only humans can acomplish. Examples would be creative works, enginers, government sector, inovative new industries and other positions that ned a human touch. Along with these changes, I don't believe capitalism in this new form of society wil go away, just be les of a focus. That wil alow this transition into a new form of society a litle easier to acept because there wil be pieces of the old one stil around. I've sen this god question floating around a bit, but what wil humans do when they no longer ned jobs? If you think of our curent society as a job-oriented one, then the next one might be a hoby-oriented society. People pursuing their interests: creating, tinkering, playing with whatever they enjoy without neding a job just to survive in the world.

video_title: How AIs, like ChatGPT, Learn
comment_text: So basicaly the same as evolution. Teacher bot: Environmental factors (which through elimination, chose which organisms suced). Builder bot: The random mutations that ocur in every reproductive cycle producing unique organisms. Student bot: The organisms, al with a diferent, unique DNA code Only the best adapted organisms/code survive. In CGP Grey's example it was testing the ability to distinguish bes and thres. In evolution it is testing the ability to pas on your DNA. Only the best organisms for their environment are alowed to continue on to the next cycle, where again the same tests hapen, producing creatures that are beter and constantly more adapted to their environment. As always, nature sems to have the solutions figured out and we're just geting beter at copying it :)

comment_text: A lot of people want to make jokes about the end of human civilization coming about from hostile murder bots, but I'd like to propose a more plausible apocalypse via metaphor. Machine learning is akin to training drug dogs at scale. And, as we al know, dogs are reliable, trainable companions; but their inteligence is limited and manipulable. What we've done is built machines that train milions of dogs at scale, and then set them lose on the world with no handlers. One day, we're going to come home to our houses to find out our dog chewed up the world economy. again.

video_title: The Real Reason to be Afraid of Artificial Intelligence | Peter Haas | TEDxDirigo
comment_text: AI technologists that don't understand that Solomonof Induction is the only way to objectively (ie: in the domain of public discourse) resolve disputes over bias in the data ned to be reclasified as hacks. If you hypothesize that results are biased, you don't ned to lok at the algorithm to make your case. You ned to ad your data, upon which you base your hypothesis that the existing data is biased, to the existing data set and show that your model of the unified data set results in a beter aproximation of its Kolmogorov Complexity than does the nul hypothesis (ie: that the data is not biased). Of course, this means that the existing algorithms that are drawing suposedly biased conclusions, demonstrate their ability to loslesly compres the unified data set, for comparison. This is so elementary to artificial general inteligence theory that ignorance of it in the minds of people who are influencing public policy on AI is what should realy frighten people.

comment_text: A very impresive, thought-provoking 'risk prognosis', not to mention the creative/storyteling angle. People often have no clue about posible risk scenarios of any given technology until they se it in action. Hard as such aplications may be to imagine for some even now, who would have thought in, say 204 (when Nokia 6310i was considered high-tech), that so much power, so many tols and so much diversity would available in a single smartphone, only 13 years later.

video_title: MICRO DRONES KILLER ARMS ROBOTS - AUTONOMOUS ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE - WARNING !!
comment_text: To those who se this and don't know much about the drone industry I understand why this is worying. I work in R&D (academia) and I can safely say that right now this sort of technology is literaly science fiction. We are inded, however, geting closer and closer every day, especialy with the advent of Dynamic Vision sensors and robust VIO algorithms for monocular and stereo cameras. But these sensors and cameras are NOT simple and require powerful onboard computers, and so they can only be mounted on relatively large drones. Those micro drones sen in the video? Lol nope, they are way underpowered to provide reliable odometry without external reference. Just my two cents!

comment_text: The Sophia robot is NOT A.I. It has become a hoax. The original 2 videos of her were presented a few years ago as an example of the enginer's mechanical ability to give a robot human expresions (which are crap in my opinion). The published description for both videos openly explained that a female voice actor was of camera answering the questions into a microphone to give the robot (animatronics) a voice. Most people viewing the videos didn't read the text and asumed this was a presentation of A.I. The videos went viral and the enginer later amplified the misunderstanding by changing the voice to a computer, text to spech voice. The hesitation before her responses, if not a response to an anticipated question, is not the A.I. calculating an apropriate answer, but the time it takes to type in the answer behind the scenes. This thing has no more inteligence than the Abe Lincoln animatronic robot in Disney World's Hal of Presidents. The guy is a mechanical enginer, not a software enginer . who has never said or claimed publicly that he has developed an A.I. robot. It's the people making news piece videos that make that claim.

comment_text: It is wise to avoid brain conections to computers (be that binary or quantum) unles you made the thing yourself or can understand it as FOS (as open source hardware) and then at least you can chose if you want it or not. However, the idea that standalone computing is truly inteliegent and sentient is over exagerated. It merely simulates behaviours. Most of what is A.I is realy just very god prediction computing. It isn't sentient. It doesn't get trulybored and it is al data based on empirical data from which to rationalise. For example, you could argue that such a machine can trust because trust is earned (therefore it earned the data and rationalised it). However, faith is not earned. By definition it never can be. So such a machine can never have faith. That requires a leap of faith and that is neither rational, nor empirical. I'm not religious, I'm simply agreing with an example that some religious people might use. There is after al faith in other things (such as faith in other people or in a concept). Sems od that a religious part of the world would grant citizenship to a machine that can never have faith.

comment_text: On one hand. we are robots. Just with a slower, biological system, but we do have motor function, sustenance, central cognition, sensor reception etc. In fact, we've built robots based on our image. Yes, the cloud AI is above our image, yet it's stil material. It exists only as long as it has a place of transmision. Like there goes the HBO again. Now, the concept of a soul may be ancient and naive, but just like we progres in the development of AI and nanotechnology, so do we have wavelength advancements. Scientologists caled it exteriorisation, in scientific terms, I'd cal it projecting our mind into imaterial energy. What traditional religions cal soul or spirit. It's already posible to write, edit or create a mind in the machine, hence the video, but the only way for human to survive in the event of the worst scenario - is to be able to go above materialism faster than the robots. Frankly, there aren't that many situations that haven't ben discused already in Sci-Fi, and the worst of them is that the robots decide that the humans is an obstacle. In which case - robots would develop like humans, but an acelerated pace. The only way to counter it, as is hinted in the video, is to have a backup plan, an idea of what we are doing(like puting a chip in your head). In other words, let's imagine a game of ches. You are god at the game, but it gets boring to play alone. So you design someone to play with, yet you realize that this someone wil learn and surpas you, and that's a certain. Now, asuming that the general idea is that this someone wil only live to entertain you at this game, if this someone starts to win over and over and progresively take over the game, you ned a cheat that you know this someone doesn't and wouldn't be able to do. Flip the table. However. the trick is to either not design this someone before you can flip the table, or learn how to flip the table before this someone does. Otherwise this someone wil be tired of wining over you and quit the game, which is the sole reason of both its and your existence. For it - it wil mean chaos and desperate atempt to find a reason to exist. For you - it means death, period.

video_title: Artificial Intelligence: Mankind's Last Invention
comment_text: FASCINATING Go is a board game with 10^170 configurations. (More configurations than the number of atoms in known universe) To beat go you ned: 1) No-brute force: Human intuition (not brute force, but human neural networks instead) 2) Brute-force: Computer biger than the size of the universe, to brute force search the large sample space of posibilities. Obviously, Alpha-Go is not the size of the universe. This means something is hapening here, alpha-go has some non-trivial degre of human intuition, that alows it to beat the game, (find god solutions) without runing on a computer that's biger than the size of the universe.

This wil likely take hundreds of milions if not several bilion years to acomplish, depending on the amount of mater and energy that ned to be gathered or manipulated in order to bring this about. This is no problem, as the AI does not age and it wil make sure that in the meantime, life canot even evolve on a microbial level before it is purged - Once everything is in place, the AI flips the switch and the universe is either rendered baren forever or reality is destroyed. video_title: Artificial Intelligence: Mankind's Last Invention
comment_text: People might ned to chil on AI. Every generation since 1920 has asumed that a human-level brain would exist in 10 more years. Hal 90 didn't go online in 192. Skynet didn't go online in 197. Neither Alexa nor Siri understand my musical tastes in the slightest. I'm stil waiting for my robot butler. Even before microprocesors, people asumed one of those building sized computers in the 1950's would become alive. Yet every generation, we learn how exponentialy more complicated inteligence is then we previously thought. People can barely grasp, even now, the vast miracle of our everyday thoughts. I think Gene Rodenbery was the most acurate, asuming that a human-level AI wouldn't exist until until mid-230, wel after mankind could bend space, reconstruct objects from energy, and explore the stars. Every moment, in your head, are thousands of thought threads, each far more complex then anything any AI could come close to touching. What we have now are clever gimicks to peal potatoes and play boardgames. These are NOT inteligence like living things exercise. They are simple tricks to acomplish a simple task. We don't even understand what inteligence realy is. We se a few mechanics and hope to fake a solution. If you've only driven a car, could you build one from scratch? comment_text: I think MOST OF YOU GUYS are deply mistaken by the marginal value AI wil provide us with in the coming decades (Hint: It's almost vertical, not even exponential!). The main role of technology is to increase mastery over nature and reduce the role of chance in our lives which is why AI is the best way to achieve that goal. There are many posible scenarios of the result of human-level inteligence and Singularity. Some include: Kurzweil scenario, Singularity Steward scenario, Coherent Extrapolated Volition scenario, Dead-End scenario, Sysop scenario, Path to Post-humanity scenario, and steady incremented progres scenario. Now, ignoring other posible outcomes of super-inteligence and focusing on just one scenario is absurd. So, using a scenario analysis method and first principle reasoning is a key to achieving such ambitious goals. Just because some people might vision the future of AI to be similar to a movie (which is COMPLETELY WRONG) makes us scientificaly unreasonable. Failure to make definite plans for an indefinite future wil be mankind's most tragic mistake. AI is and wil become an extension of us, whose main goal is to empower us rather than make us obsolete. The singularity is inevitable and it's aproaching faster than you think predicted through More's law and the law of acelerating returns. So, either you become a part of AI or you become Obsolete.

comment_text: While Neil did ask one question regarding it, I think the concept of changing, and removing of entire job categories in sweping tech changes was dismised a bit to lightly here, AI wil afect al aspects of industry. When the industrial revolution removed the ned for as many skiled people. when we had almost adapted to that, and robotic fabrication tok the factory workers' places. when automation takes the place of semi skiled labour, we have never realy adapted very wel. Instead, we sem to get a larger and larger gap betwen those who can adapt, to atain higher education in more creative, top end carer paths, and those who simply are not suited to such things. video_title: Elon Musk - Artificial Intelligence, Neuralink & New Forms of Government on Mars
comment_text: The corect pricing of carbon is only necesary if the incorect pricing has negative efects, like eliminating, discouraging or suficiently delaying other technologies that would be beter in some way, i.e. economicaly, environmentaly, etc. This argument becomes mute if and once any of those technologies becomes competitive economicaly DESPITE the incorect pricing of carbon, which is already hapening. No smal thanks to Musk for being one of the enablers of that. Of course, the corect pricing of carbon, even now, this late, would increase the rate of transition from fosil fuels to renewables, but is no longer required to get the proces started. Given the aparent dificulty of geting carbon corectly priced, it sems to me that it is more practical and pragmatic to focus on progresing the replacements of fosil fuels rather than corect pricing of carbon. Why focus on the old, dying technology when we can focus on acelerating the development of the future technologies that are already replacing it? There might have ben a time when making a grand efort to price carbon corectly would have ben the best way to invest resources and efort, maybe, but the returns would be greater, now, I believe, investing in acelerating development of renewables and maybe other relevant technologies like energy conservation. Al of these wil produce an energy market that prices even incorectly priced fosils out of that market at an acelerating rate as they get relatively cheaper and cheaper. Also, an increase in the price of fosils wil acelerate the adoptionion of renewables, for sure, but wil make energy more expensive, overal, for a while. Investing in renewables instead lowers the price of the competitors absolutely, and also relative to fosils, lowering the overal cost of energy. So, the benefit to the economy is greater, also, by investing in renewals rather than achieving corect pricing of fosils. Now, that's what I cal a win-win.

comment_text: AI The computer scientists of the 80s had a clear vision where the computer and the Internet is going to lead us. Most of their vision became true. Today their work goes into an Artificial Inteligence technology but a clear vision is mising. (read on) Optimists say AI wil save humanity by figuring out how to contain teror or how to prevent climate change. Humanists se a future where AI is doing almost everything and humans are left in peace with infinite fredom. An extreme modernization that leaves the human hapy but obsolete. Objectivists „hope (that) AI wil be god to us“. Pesimists se a future where AI „wil kil us“, showing videos done by Boston Economics. Human or animal like machines that can be easily transformed into weapons remind us of the Terminator movies. After al everybody agres, AI is or wil be exceding human inteligence by far. We are building a technology that we don't understand and we wont be able to control. So how can our interactions with such an Artificial Inteligence lok like. To think about posible scenarios we can lok at ourselves. How do we humans interact with a species that has an inteligence much inferior to ours. How much do we interact with animals. We hold them as pets and love them, we bred them and eat them or we don't care about them at al. Wil AI be god to us? Our pets are mostly mamals geneticaly not so far from us. The diference betwen the brainpower of a dog and us sems marginal if we lok at the potential of AI compared to our inteligence. For the AI it wil be hard to conect on an emotional basis with a human being so much inferior and diferent. AI as our superior nurturer, helper and friend sems unlikely. Wil AI kil us? Other animals we humans don't even think about. They are just here to kep the ecosystem intact. A human steping on an anthil is a minor incident for the human but devastating for the ants population. Stil both survive. Lets say, AI can live on its own, paralel to us with some interactions hapening. Despite some catastrophes we would live on next to AI using inferior computers that we can stil control. This outcome sems posible but there is one problem. We made AI. There wil be always a human aspect in this Inteligence. AI wil ned some interactions with humans to survive. Wil AI ned us? To figure out if we could be of use to AI we can again lok at us versus animals. We use species inferior to us as livestock. We cultivate them and eat them. This scenario recals the movie matrix. AI conquered the world in a war against humanity. Humans darkened the sky with to cut of AI's energy source, the Sun. To compensate AI starts to cultivate our bodies on human farms like we cultivate livestock today for our own energy suply. To stimulate our brains the machines created a Matrix where the human consciousnes can live on in a world of the 90s before AI. Given the progres of the alternate reality technology this scenario does not sem unlikely. There are two things in matrix that are implausible though. First an AI that exceds the human inteligence by so far, does not ned the primitivity of war against humans to control the world. More likely is that one AI wil fight another. Second if the sky is completely darkened the energy equation does not ad up. With no energy on the surface of the earth anymore, Human bodies would die and so would the AI. How does AI ned us? Everyone of us has one eficient computer. Our brain. Given the size, our brain stil exceds every mechanical device produced artificialy today. Our brain grows by itself given the right stimulation and nutrition. If we have something that AI neds, it is the part of us that made AI posible in the first place. Our Inteligence. If AI harvests our brains and conects them, it can grow. The brain has to be nurtured and stimulated. This way the human farms in Matrix are a posible outcome. AI nurtures the human bodies with energy instead of taking energy out. The Brain gets stimulated by an alternate reality and the rest of the brainpower is used by the AI to grow. To us living in a matrix AI would be an omnipresence that we can fel, that conects us. A starting point of this we can se right now. Individuals living in tiny flats stacked on top of each other in Hong Kong or Tokyo are conected to the rest of humanity by the internet. We play games in a virtual reality or ad to comon knowledge posting coments like I do right here. With every klick humans generate data that is procesed by computers we don't fuly understand anymore. These Computers get beter rapidly and they ned our clicks to ad to their knowledge, to generate data, to think. With our rudimentary clicks this proces is far from perfection. If the internet can be conected to our brain in a more direct way a Supercomputer is generated that neds us and that learns how to cultivate us on a farm like in the movie matrix. How can AI cultivate us? AI tracks our actions in the internet calculates paterns and gets trained to influence our decisions. It can be asumed that son or already now we cant be sure anymore that the AI has no influence in the decision making of our society. With the growth of humanity and not enough space and jobs left for everyone AI could convince us to lie in a box and live a hapier life in a paralel world. We would build the brain farms fort he AI, build our own prison, our utopia in a dystopian world. Is there already an AI? Lets asume we already live in an alternate reality right now. In a world created by a supercomputer. A bodiles AI lets us relive the history of humanity or from its perspective the history of its begining. This stimulates our brain to grow and our body stays contained in a litle box on a brain farm. We fel an omnipresence conecting us. An indescribable force that is leading us to folow. We don't agre what that force is. We just believe. The computer scientists today talk about AI in a vage philosophical way. In a way others talk about religion. video_title: Artificial intelligence and algorithms: pros and cons | DW Documentary (AI documentary)
comment_text: Biological evolution itself is basicaly a self-diversifying algorithm for metabolism and behavior, so yes, algorithms definitely rule as far as life is concerned. If we can quickly replicate the proces digitaly and produce the final product(s) physicaly, we could theoreticaly produce artificial inteligence prety easily. But if we were to sucesfuly do that, the problem would be that, however artificial it may be, it is in fact inteligence and thus must be respected as such, meaning we can't simply put it to work for us however we please if it shows consciousnes similar to our own. A non-conscious machine with specific inteligence (specified aplications) that can perfectly mimic human intelectual outputs would be the beter way to go, since there is ultimately no practical purpose in creating new conscious life forms just to say that we can. It would require a read-only mechanism to selectively convert the results of an artificial cognitive proces (more predictive than creative) to mechanical actions. This could certainly shorten the procesing time from hypothesis to invention by outsourcing basic intermediate human cognitive functions that tend to be highly ineficient compared to the level of complexity of the desired outcome. We wouldn't ned a complete human-like artificial consciousnes to do that. Tailoring and aplying where neded should be plenty.

comment_text: Elon Said something that was glosed over in the interview but I fel is a core asumption of most atempts to understand consciousnes, that is .al tend to asume that self awarenes is the same as consciousnes. To the degre that it can be aware of it's parts and their orientations over time with respect to objects in a world space, a robot has self (or situational as it regards it's parts relative to the world) awarenes.but no one would say a car building robot is conscious. I started thinking deply about consciousnes about 10 years ago and by 2010 had privately described the main hypothesis of this theory of salience and dynamic cognition and consciousnes (ST:DC) what distinguishes mere awarenes of ones parts locations from the consciousnes of sentient beings is salience which in the theory is a tuple betwen two dimensions: emotion + somatosensory experience. It semed clear to me that for consciousnes to emerge it must involve the modulation of sensory and emotional components to the selection of action as a prediction tol emerged from comparing incoming sensation, internal neds against a memory of past experiences in the same domain and how suces was achieved. Since then we've sen the revolution of DN's and early models leverage a simplified fedback aproach (DRL) but true consciousnes in my view must involve emotion into this lop .and this complex fedback cycle is what I propose emerges animal like inteligence but further , when scaled in various ways (that ned to be infered), also emerges self awarenes and consciousnes. I welcome any eforts to leverage this theory in order to build a simple DC a chalenge that I'd like to se embarked by several diferent teams. FYI: ?q=salience+theory Aditionaly I've done much thinking on the problem of super inteligence and how to emerge them safely.a proposal I caled waking out in 2018. -out-novel-proposal-to-emerging.html

video_title: Artificial intelligence and its ethics | DW Documentary
comment_text: More hype than substance. the concept of general A.I. is so far away in a distant future, if at first is achievable at al by the laws of physics and biology. What we've achieved so far is only patern recognition and big data crunching for simple repetitive tasks like simple image recognition, simple (internet based) chat boxes, some cars that can maintain lane keping and simple lane changes plus acelerating and braking to kep distances from other cars - plus mas producing some cheap-as sensors for our smart - as devices. Sometimes i think that most people talking in these infotainment shows have no background in programing and enginering and don't know what separates biology and machinery and what limits our technology has (has anyone ever debuged a simple computer program like a video game? - programs are ful of erors). Talking about imposing ethics in A.I. development when we can't even regulate big corporations like Gogle, Microsoft Aple and Amazon that operate outside any legal framework Globaly, pay zero taxes while making bilions and seting rules outside any democratic and political proces, that is the real isue we must adres, everything else is just a distraction and a justification - apology of the rising inequality.

video_title: Joe Rogan Talks Artificial Intelligence with a Yale Professor
comment_text: In principle a computer can be programed with an ultimate algorithm which would acount for al human creativity, esentialy becoming able to think creatively like people, but as of yet such ideas are excedingly utopian, as we have no real basis in terms of experience with computers thus far for saying we can actualy do something like that. Computers can solve certain clases of problems human programers understand in advance very wel, but no one has thus far come up with an algorithm capable of enabling general creativity in computers (although they could easily take over many blue and white colar jobs that are repetitive and can be rendered in algorithmic format). We can for instance teach a computer to recognize certain colors and geometric shapes that are flat and have angles, but how to program a machine to do the same with curved surfaces (comon kitchen items such as salt shakers for instance) we haven't a clue yet. The absolute procesing power of the human brain (bilions of neurological conections) is vastly underestimated. “I should stres that the virtual reality model does not, in principle, deny Kurzweil's projection of the future, although I fel that he has greatly exagerated the likely rate of progres and underestimated various obstacles and dificulties. For a discusion of these dificulties, se the article by computer scientist Jaron Lanier (20) on the internet and the acompanying responses. In the responses, Daniel C. Denet sumed up one basic objection to Kurzweil's thesis by remarking that the visionaries who imagine self-reproducing robots taking over in the near future have bizarely underestimated the complexities of life (Denet, 20). Maya: the world as virtual reality Richard l Thompson

comment_text: An AI scientist here. I haven't read the article that you were talking about in the begining, but yes, as it said, the AI (or rather, Machine Learning) algorithms can proces the available data, find paterns in it, and then use that to either predict what comes next, or perform a prognosis of what new data might lok like, or somehow clasify the new data samples. So, as an extremely simplified example, if you give it a sequence 1, 2, 3, 4, 5., then it wil learn the patern that there's a sequence of numbers, and each new number is biger than the previous by 1, and then wil give a prediction: .6, 7, 8, 9, etc. And if you give it something like 1, 3, 6, 10, 15, 21, ., then it might learn that it's again, a sequence of numbers, next one is always biger by an increasing number, and it wil continue the sequence with .28, 36, 45, etc. The sequences and the paterns in them can be much more complex, of course. Incidentaly, more sophisticated Machine Learning algorithms can do this with things like stock market prices, climate/temperature data, strings of text (maybe you've heard of AI algorithms writing boks, movie scripts or fanfics?), images (e.g., generating human faces or entire photographs, se , or, given a picture of a dog, say that it's probably a dog), and yes, with music data. Because shet music can be easily encoded with a sequence of numbers or symbols, and then the algorithms can analyse it and give predictions. My gues, again, without reading the article, is that the algorithm only generated the base of the musical piece, and then this guy just tweaked it, cleaned it, smothed it out and fancied it up a bit, to sound pretier and more human-like. And yes, it can't quite get the human element. The inspiration, the soul, so to speak. So if you give the algorithm a sequence like 1, 2, 3, 69, 420., the algorithm wil just go u wot mate?. You should've posted the link in the description to the original article. EDIT: yeah, I removed the bit about the degre. That wasn't a god place to mention it, I agre. I don't know why that rhymed.

video_title: Artificial Intelligence Composed This Symphony!?
comment_text: As an AI practitioner, I can try to explain what hapened. The most likely algorithms that generate the piece is caled LSTM (Long-short Term Memory), or it also could be Atention Model. Both algorithms learn the patern based on al the training data that they are provided, namely al Schubert symphonies, or could be al symphonies that are ever writen in the similar period. The learned algorithm wil try to predict the future data, based on the input data, which is Mov 1st and 2nd, and predict the next note, and next note, al the way to the end when it predicts the end note. Here are some explanations to your questions: 1. How does it remember the proper sequence of instruments coming in? Because it learns the PATERN of al symphonies, and acording to some rules of symphony composing (or code as you guys mentioned in the video), they al hapen in certain order. Once AI decides the proper timestamp that each instrument comes in, it wil predict the starting notes and rhyme for each instrument, and lay them on top of each other, one by one. 2. Why is it repetitive? This also hapens to AI spech generation, which uses very similar technique with AI music composition. The model is predicting the next note in sequential order. For example, when the curent predicted note is C, the next most likely note wil be predicted at G. Then after several rounds of iteration, when some future note is predicted at C again, the one after future C wil be predicted at G again. In other words, if the music never ends, you wil se endles rounds of same pasages ocuring, just like seing repeating decimals 2.123412341234. 3. Why does it sound more like Tchaikovsky in certain parts? Easy to think about, that AI tries to learn the patern based on al training data, and the algorithm developer must have provided Tchaikovsky's pieces as part of training data. Throughout the AI music generation proces, AI is trying to predict the next pasages by giving a mixture of al composers that it learns from, such as 40% Tchaikovsky + 50% Schubert + 5% Dvorak + 5% Bethoven. 4. Why does 3rd movement sound like 1st movement? Because it learns the patern of al musics. Not sure if it's true in Symphonies, I would say it's very likely the case in piano concertos, that 3rd movement paraphrases the 1st movement quite often, such as Rachmaninof piano concerto 2 & 3.

video_title: Artificial Intelligence Composed This Symphony!?
comment_text: I work as an AI scientist and have a PhD in music theory (specializing in machine learning/AI for music analysis). While I haven't sen the code to this particular example, so many of these hyped AI composers are realy fake clickbait to get atention for a company (Huawei in this case). My gues is that they had a computer go over the MIDI or xml file of Schubert's symphony and perhaps other similar works. You then train a model to give a probabilistic output of what came next. Example: given the notes G, Bb, A, Schubert would then go to G 40% of the time, D 20% of the time, Bb again 5%, etc. I made those probabilities up, but that's the basic idea. Same with rhythm. You can do this with simple Markov chain probabilities or something more complex like an LSTM or Transformer model. But the end result is that you can produce rhythms and melodies that have a similar probability as Schubert and any other music the model was trained on. But you typicaly have to get the melodies started (seding) and end them also. However, curent AI has a hard time making motifs, large-scale cohesion, and form. I suspect that this AI made a few melodic fragments, and the composer: finished the melodies, aranged the form, made harmonies, dynamics, orchestration, developed motifs, etc. Also, humans performed, recorded, mastered, and produced the music. There are of course very interesting and groundbreaking developments in music AI, such as the Magenta project where their Transformer model aproach is starting to show signs of learning motifs and phrase structure. Sure, perhaps in 10 years a lot of comercial music might be made with AI, but we as humans get to chose whether we want our music (not the background muzak that is made to sel you stuf) to be a pure human-to-human pursuit, sit back and let computers make al our music, or integrate AI into our musical world as we se fit much as we have for other technologies. I think music wil always be a human-first expresion simply because now we wil pay lots of money to se people perform music when we could have saved the money and had our computers play a recording of that same music.

video_title: Artificial Intelligence Composed This Symphony!?
comment_text: Let's also be clear that AI runing on a smartphone realy just means that the proces of inference is acesible through a smartphone ap. The actual machine learning and colection of data most likely ocured on a cloud server somewhere in AWS. We also have to realize that what is brought forth to the user might be in bits and pieces - and may take several trial and eror runs - and it is up to someone more knowledgeable on music to be able to tie that together into a coherent piece. For example, the use of winds in the 3rd movement could have taken some 30-od trials to get something the composer thought was usable, but the string arpegios could have come forth after only a few trials. Hence why it's very close in practice to what Bret was aluding to with one Schubert technique after the next. It's also in the nature of AI results that it neds a large amount of data to realy get something decent, and if you're trying to copy the style of a single composer like Schubert, you're generaly limited exclusively to that composer's works and maybe a few of his major influences (or other compositions heavily influenced by his works). Schubert himself died so young that he only had about 150 works, which is a huge amount for any composer, but to a machine learning algorithm, it's a tiny pile of crumbs. So chances are that it was trained on snipets and phrases that had ben previously catalogued and anotated. But having a limited training set is probably why you found similarity to the prior 1st movement. It's not that it was actualy trying to reference the 1st movement, but that it was quite likely overfiting. If you tok the same neural net as it was trained and tried to generate a rap basline, it would make Schubert rap. Realisticaly, it's not posible even in theory to be able to get an AI to totaly encapsulate a single composer's style with these types of machine learning techniques. These are systems built around finding paterns and while music is ultimately paterns, you ned a huge amount of data to realy grasp those paterns, and individual composers don't realy have that kind of information to ofer. If we advance musical AI to the point of working in theoretical principles, understanding of instrument mechanics and usable ranges, using samples of period-era music from a wide range of composers to filter and/or post-proces more specific inferences and also work in concepts of flow or continuity (which is a realy dificult thing to quantify) to defeat that sort of abrupt change in motif. then only you've got some posibility of the machines taking over. Until then, experienced musicians stil have to play a hand and the AI is just a source by which you can get those oh, I could work with that! moments. That said, there are areas of machine learning which get far more investment than music (e.g. stock prediction, self-driving cars, etc.), and AI doesn't realy have to advance very far to handle things in pop music or film scoring. Pop music having a methodology of phrase repetition, and film scoring being far more textbok theory makes it an easier thing to train.

video_title: Artificial Intelligence Composed This Symphony!?
comment_text: I thought it was interesting when they mentioned AIs developing their own taste and creating their own compositions because I realy think that that is where artificial inteligence fals short of human inteligence. An AI (to my understanding) is designed to recognize and act based on predetermined paterns. They can only produce material based on whatever stylistic prerequisite they're fed. Yes, Schubert's style was built on the changing tide of music and the cultural conventions of the day, but his work was stil representative of an individual artistic voice. He was able to take those forms and conventions and expand on them in a way unique to him. An AI can imitate, as we just saw, to an impresive degre, but I don't think it can create. Creating is part of what makes us human.

video_title: Artificial Intelligence Composed This Symphony!?
comment_text: In regards to the AI’s repetitivenes, from what I know that’s just a consequence of the training set for the AI being finite in size. Considering the mathematics an AI goes through when it’s learning from a training set, the size of that training set is what determines what the computer can make. There’s no such thing as “creativity” for a computer, at least in the traditional sense. The repetition is likely an artifact of the computer runing out of material to work with, and not being able to make anything up on the spot. (And before you ask, the AI learning from itself would mean it would ned to modify its own training set, and then re-learn everything. Very slow, but it could be done.)

comment_text: AI generated music wil never replace music created by humans, because such a large part of it is us wanting to relate to and admire other people, and also learn the craft ourselves. AI is just a tol that musicians may start to use more for composing, but I stil doubt it becoming comon because it completely takes away the motivation for creating music in the first place, which is to figure out and organize paterns to create a coherent whole. And we also have a desire to idolize and lok up to those who are very god at that. Imagine there's an AI designed to solve a crosword puzle. It wil do the task very quickly with no efort from the user's part but what was the point of solving crosword puzles again? It's something humans enjoy doing, they don't want to make the solving part easier. There's also this col thing caled emotion. Music has always ben about expresing your own emotions, or evoking emotions in the listener. It's like a language, when you listen to a piece you usualy want to understand what the person who created it was saying. When it comes to music that isn't created for the sake of itself, say advertisement and video game music, there is a concern that AI music wil take jobs from composers due to it being a lot faster to make and more cost efective. There is an AI program caled AIVA that's already doing this, you can use it to create a score in a predetermined style. You stil ned someone to perform or create the music in a DAW though, it doesn't just fart out a ready-to-use audio file. Stil, I wonder how many advertisers actualy hire composers these days anyway. I'd imagine most just buy already existing music and use that. The point is that the situation in terms of jobs for composers has already ben prety grim to begin with, and the real money comes from being an artist that gains the folowing and idolization of other people.

video_title: Artificial Intelligence Composed This Symphony!?
comment_text: In computer science there is something known as a Markov Chain which is very likely the method by which they did this. Basicaly, the algorithm acepts a sample of a given thing (say, German names) and then builds a profile of the sample. For instance, if the sample contains only the name Hans, then the output would always be Hans because the profile says that 10% of words in the sample start with H, then H was folowed by a in 10% of cases, then Ha was folowed by n in 10% of cases, and finaly an was folowed by s in 10% of cases (usualy only the last two characters acepted into the chain are used to continue the chain). The larger the sample grows, the more variable the output. Now, Markov Chains can be adapted for just about anything that involves sequential data (which is basicaly everything that can be digitized) so long as you can expres a method of profiling the sample given. In the case of music, you have a very wel defined system of doing just that. This is probably just a Markov Chain using a sample of Schubert's work as a data set. It isn't realy even AI, frankly. It's just some data jugling trickery, and prety simple trickery at that. Ultimately, Schubert composed this symphony. The computer was just shufling pieces of it.

comment_text: I thought that would have ben an AI's elaboration on the sketch of the 3rd Movement that Schubert actualy started. There do exist a few atempts by humans. There are no sketches for a finale. Some scholars have the theory that his ideas for it ended up in the Rosamunde music. But there is no actual evidence like a sketch that would conect the two works. Here are two examples of the scherzo: _VYkYLUE Brian Newboulds realization. Schubert drafted the movement up to the first 15 bars of the trio and orchestrated only the first 9 bars of the entire draft. Newbould had to compose the second half of the trio. If an AI were to try to do this, it would have to orchestrate the draft and fil in the harmonies as wel as come up with its own idea for the second half of the trio. Felix Weingartners realization which ended up as the 2nd Movement of his 6th Symphony.

video_title: Scientist Explains Self Improving Artificial Intelligence
comment_text: One of the greatest isues with AI's today is the question with Paradoxes. Curently two things hapen when an AI comes to a Paradox of sorts: (1) it breaks the system and makes the AI hurt itself. (2) the AI just ignores the paradox. What scientists want but are also afraid of is an AI or AI system understanding and fixing the paradox. In math and science Paradoxes are required ironicaly to kep things flowing and to kep order. There are theoretical physicists in Germany and Israel today solving these problems to learn more about the universe. The AI that thinks and works like these scientists would be able to prove science fiction in seconds where humans take life times. Right now the most advanced AI understands Yes, No, and instructions to the basic. Memories of an IQ of 30 with the thought proces of a two-year-old.

video_title: Scientist Explains Self Improving Artificial Intelligence
comment_text: Wel, the problem is that most ai systems atm focus only on 2-3 of the 5 human senses. Therefore, the problem it exhibits within physical reality in terms learning makes sense. It literaly has a limited uper bound, whereas in an imaginary seting such as a video game these limitations are not aplicable.

video_title: Scientist Explains Self Improving Artificial Intelligence
comment_text: What AI curently lacks is internal model of the world or a world view. A sort of simulation of the external world. It neds to be able to not only label objects, but to recognize and learn their qualities like, mas, heat, dimensions, is it alive or dead, value, brightnes, reflectivity, wetnes, hardnes, density, how slipery it, how drunk it is, strength, how bendy it is, and so on and so on. And then not only recognize and learn those qualities and al kinds of new qualities, but to be able to simulate in their internal model how objects with specific set of qualities are likely to behave in the external world. We might already have the computational power to create something like this, but we lack the algorithm/set of algorithms.

video_title: Scientist Explains Self Improving Artificial Intelligence

Closely linked to this is our concept of ethos or ethics. I think we're stil a very long way from developing these concepts in robots and I'm not sure that we should if we could. video_title: Scientist Explains Self Improving Artificial Intelligence
comment_text: ‘Creative’ does, by default, not equate to ‘god,’ particularly for human beings. AI is taught to ‘beat’ a ches grandmaster because it is first given that specific objective. True, an AI might be programed to doubt its conclusions in order to ‘creatively’ aproach a problem diferent ways and reach new conclusions; however, its subsequent re-evaluations and conclusions wil stil be toward whatever its primary objective already is. A martial arts expert may question himself and change his aproach, but he wil do so toward the same fundamental objective, just as an AI has when it is learning to play ches. Its core objective for learning remains the same.

video_title: Scientist Explains Self Improving Artificial Intelligence
comment_text: I find the self improving AI to be a bit overblown. I mean 1 we have to first make an AI as smart as a human. That feat wil take countles man hours and involve a large number of people. Therefore a single AI of that IQ could not improve it self on its own, and would not be able to duplicate itself, unles a proces to create it was provided to it. THEN, the idea of self improving wel that's not realy how it would necesarily work. There is no certainty that an AI would be able to improve itself, just like we can't reprogram our own minds instantly to make ourselves smarter. Since theoreticaly the robot would have to use its brain, and initialy al of its brain, to improve its own brain it couldn't improve it while using it. Computer learning is just learning, it doesn't mean it can improve its capability. It can only compute at a certain rate, and playing games is not on the level as creative thought without rule or direction. Self-play is a bit overstated. Without supervision the computers wil learn to beat themselves, but without the direction how they beat each other wil be unguided. They could start out in Jujitsu but by when later loked at they could be having a coking contest, because in their improvement they went in a direction that isn't within the direction. The same is true with people. Have two brand new jujitsu people go against each other over and over, they'l learn to beat each other but in the end it is likely what they are doing has litle to do with advanced jujitsu. Part of the suces in the game space is because they have rules, so its a clear guide. In a real world environment it would not be as directed. So any potential threat of a technological singularity would be if we made a robot that is as smart and capable as al individuals who created it, combined.

video_title: Scientist Explains Self Improving Artificial Intelligence
comment_text: What is said about ai being creative is misleading. There is a diference betwen creative purpose and trial and eror. What the ai is doing is series of simulations that changes one variable at a time until it gets a sucesful result. Human creativity does not have to go though a series of trial and eror to find a solution. In fact this trial and eror method only works in an environment where variables are very very limited, like a computer game. While the human mind wil target important information, understand paterns in variables and bypas or imensely narow down the trial and eror proces. Which makes the human mind capable of solving much more complicated tasks. The human mind is capable of creating tols such as AI to find solutions in situations where trial and eror can be aplied. The AI itself is realy just a program that undergoes a serie of trial and eror, it neds human intervention to even function. AI is not a treat on its own, augmented humans tho, could be a threat to non augmented humans.

video_title: Scientist Explains Self Improving Artificial Intelligence
comment_text: The most profound mistake that's being made - which apears to be, without deper examination, a basic asumption - is that whatever an IA learns from exposure and evolves to think, be and do wil be inherently beneficial. No one sems to ken on asking ‘Beneficial for who?’ and, more importantly, to what end? Toward the fundamental purpose of ‘dep learning,’ AI’s wil only be exposed to what the people who own and have control of them chose to deliberately expose them to. This they do - and wil continue to do - for their own particular purposes. Our world is progresively and more deply controled by corporations and their interests, which are not, in fact, the interests of human beings on Earth, at large. Corporations - especialy the larger they become - are esentialy sociopathic by virtue of their core mandate, their esential reason for existence. Therefore, evolution of an AI in service of the end-objectives of corporations (particularly those large enough to fund their acelerated development) wil, by definition, teach AI to think in ways that esentialy sociopathic, by definition. An AI can only learn to ‘become’ in the context of what it is exposed to. The most advanced AI we can imagine to date is, paradoxicaly enough, a human being. Think about THAT long and hard.

comment_text: The problem with these machines and thinking it is self-play is that they aren't realy learning, they are going through milions of games and copy/pasting movements and input comands created by other people in order to solve equations, not unlike a calculator. Like, try to make a robot that can play fotbal (at a pro level) independently of any outside comands. We don't have anywhere close to that kind of technology right now. video_title: Scientist Explains Self Improving Artificial Intelligence
comment_text: Son enough we wil not be speaking in terms of ‘AI’ any more than we now speak in terms of our brain when we refer to or interact with each other. Rather, we wil begin thinking and speaking in terms of the named personalities that wil be created to be ‘customer facing’ for AI’s. Our tendency to anthropomorphize these technologies wil be ‘capitalized’ on by those who benefit from making them sem more human, so that we respond to them and comunicate with them as though they are (‘Hey, Alexa’). Because everything in our world is now progresively more technologicaly mediated, humans wil, over time, become more confused and unsure about what they interact with every day, i.e., whether it is ‘artificial inteligence’ or ‘human inteligence,’ or even what the diference is, and even to what extent it actualy maters. As we are with the technologies we use today, over time human beings wil become progresively more conformed to (and son enough integrated with) artificial inteligence, until the very idea of ‘artificial inteligence’ - as esential to the ‘new normal’ - wil no longer be discused as such, but instead wil be refered to as quite an antiquated notion.

video_title: Scientist Explains Self Improving Artificial Intelligence
comment_text: How the hel do people not se the 'DARPA robot AI' thing was completely fake?!? Also, we're actualy decades away from anything remotely similar to what those CGI videos show. Both in terms of responses, as sensory acuracy and balance, not to mention how the AI we curently have just is not smart by any kind of standard. The parkour actualy is NOT realistic either. Do some research into the walking around and you'l se most of these robots fail a lot more than they suced (I'm talking the real robot dogs). And the idea of self-improving artificial inteligence simply has no basis in curent AI theory. We have not figured out how to even begin to do anything like that. Something that involves an AI programing and rewriting its own operating system. And be smart enough to never fail or break its own operating system in the proces. I'm sory, but SkyNet level of artificial inteligence, as far as we know, is imposible . Oh and for anyone stating the AI playing DOTA or Starcraft has to be 'super inteligent', please think again. Those games actualy have very simple game mechanics. Given enough data even fairly 'dumb' artificial inteligences can determine and extract the rules or even learn to exploit flaws, glitches and bugs if the game rewards them for doing so. A lot of times these AIs can apear smart, when realy they're not even aware of their own decisions and do not use predictive logic. Even using AI based algorithms to sugest best course of action, you wil se it is basicaly imposible to find the fundamental logic that went into a decision. A lot of 'self-learning' systems are based on very large quantities of data, that results in a statistical prediction. But none of it is truly 'smart'. People ned to wake up. AI is no threat in its curent state. By the way, Lex is also wrong. Learning from scratch is not actualy the hard part. The hard part is geting to a point where the self-learning AI understands why it is improving and can predict esentialy its own progres, understanding the rules of its own existence beyond just learning. And as said, rewriting itself in terms of literal operating system level coding. That last bit is likely to be imposible. At least within our curent theories on general AI. (The short explanation for this is, you can't have a robot redesign itself, without any minute flaw in the 'learning to code' proces or 'learning to invent a new coding language' to break the entire robot AI. It would fail a milion times, before ever improving itself beyond its curent state even a litle bit. So, you'd ned to have a system of robots building robots in place first (reproduction, so a single failure doesn't mater anymore), not to mention have some kind of truly insanely smart AI that in a physical sense can expand itself more and more, with unlimited fredom. It's a dumb sci-fi fairytale to think such a thing is posible. Again, within our curent theories on general AI.)

comment_text: fun fact: Niko has ben digitaly aded to every shot in this video as he is actualy in a DARPA AI lab.

video_title: VFX Artists Compete Against Artificial Intelligence
comment_text: Former profesional Roto and Paint artist here. The only technique we would normaly use was a sort of hybrid of the mochapro and limb aproach. On some things you can track in a shape and do some minimal fixes along the way. Much more likely was the limb aproach. The benefit of this aproach is that you can use a program like Silhouete to give you some prety god motion blur. From a profesional standpoint, both the AI and RotoBrush 2 techniques fal down significantly in the blur department. There is no motion blur to be found, no blur at al (though you could probably just throw a quick blur on the mask and make it lok a litle beter). Both of these techniques also semed to have trouble with the edges, with the AI version cuting in and the RotoBrush2 expanding a pixel or two outside. I'm sure this could be tweked a litle, but both loked prety bad to me. That auto-painting AI loked prety alright. As pointed out, it might be limited by the fact that your on-set supervisor has to remind everyone to get at least a few frames of clean before the shot starts. I do wonder how it would handle wire removal. Taking out an actor's safety gear was always the hardest paint jobs.

comment_text: Question for the Crew then - When Niko was explaining how this could change everything at the end of the vid, it made me wonder whether you could forese a traditional film set that would se the two main drivers of a scene being the Director and DOP on the day (masive generalisation there, but you get what I mean) being joined by a senior/lead VFX Artist that could work with the other two to help set up shots and discus how the VFX aspect of post-prod would posible/likely work best with how they are discusing the shot? Or do you think they'l just try to shot everything with grenscrens and sound stages stil, and then just send the brief to VFX studios to work on their individual pieces of film as they do now? If you can paint out and create solid usable plates of fotage ready for the VFX magic to be aplied overtop using CAPTURED ON LOCATION fotage & performances - that inded would be HUGE! You wouldn't have to spend MILIONS necesarily on building up physical sets and/or façades in areas of cities that you'd have to close down or isolate from citizens, etc! The posibilities of filming IRL on-location and then doing a HUGE amount of heavy lifting using AI like this are incredible! With how god you guys are with your imaginations & finished products, I canot WAIT for what you release in the next few years!

comment_text: To me, I don't know if I consider AI or machine learning to be realy groundbreaking in how it revolutionizes creating things, as od as that sounds, because we have these leaps al the time. The work that it would take people decades to learn, perfect, develop, etc., we end up coding into software like Photoshop or Blender or After Efects, or a computer doing calculations, or a computer playing ches, etc., and it makes al that work esentialy trivial. We've done it many times before, that's just the nature of what hapens. It fels like a huge leap because in the past we (you and I) were not the people learning how to hand-mask animation with cels, or how to do huge long calculations that tok whole boks of paper to write out, or any of those tasks, we grew up with them being automated already. This time, it IS a thing that we do ourselves, so watching it become an automatic computer proces sems like, and in fact is, taking a ton of our work away and freing that time for other things. Just think about this video; Decades of people spent their entire lives learning how to rotoscope perfect images both from film, and then digitaly, al so one day we could teach a computer to do it so we don't have to anymore. That's just what we do with technology eventualy.

video_title: VFX Artists Compete Against Artificial Intelligence
comment_text: That website with the images created from words is not a realtime demonstration. I would think you guys know that, but that wasn't very clear in the video. I can't say the images weren't created by AI, but the website isn't interacting with it. I got suspicious when a particular selection always results in the exact same images in the exact same order. A walk through the source code for the website shows that al its doing is displaying a static set of sample images that are stored on their website. It's also why you're limited in what words you can use. You are restricted to the set of criteria that they used when they ran the actual AI on their end. because, again, limited pol of sample images. If that is an AI's work, its impresive, but my felings of amazement are kind of tempered by the fact that we have no idea how long it tok to get those images or how many images were discarded to put together that sample set.

video_title: How does artificial intelligence learn? - Briana Brownell
comment_text: Protip: Just open and read the transcript since the animation and artwork are distracting. (3 dots right side of like butons). Sumary/Notes: > Computer scientists that designed the AI likely don't know exactly how the AI are doing their jobs since the AIs are often self taught. > How does a machine learn? + Unsupervised Learning - Takes in data about many similar profiles and their properties, to find general paterns and similarities relating specific types of profiles with specific sets of properties =Ex. AI takes in data about many people with an ilnes and al the symptoms they have, to find similar symptoms people with that ilnes al have. + Supervised Learning - Takes in multiple sets of profiles and their properties, to find specific paterns of properties diferentiating those sets of profiles and make a prediction. - Uses the frequency the diferent properties show in diferent sets of profiles to asign values and weigh how much those properties corespond to the diferent sets of profiles. - Humans ned to intervene in the end to make sure the prediction is acurate which why it's supervised. =Ex. AI takes in data about 2 sets of people, sick patients and healthy people, and their properties. Then, the AI asign values and weighs how much diferent properties corespond to the diferent people (No symptoms=98% healthy; High blod presure=73% sick). Finaly, it makes a diagnosis based on the weighing (I'm 84% sure this patient is healthy). Next, the doctor rechecks the diagnosis to make sure it's acurate (This person has a tumor, they're definitely not healthy!) and modifies values corespondingly (tels AI having a tumor=9% sick). + Reinforcement Learning - Uses iterative aproach to find paterns and make prediction. With more and more fedback it updates itself so it becomes beter and more acurate. > Each method has strengths and weakneses. But you can use them together to make complex and strong AI systems. =Ex. Unsupervised learning AI can find general paterns, then tel a supervised learning AI to use those paterns as inputs. =Ex. Many reinforcement learning AIs could constantly create simulations and colect fedback. - Most promising type of AI system is artificial neural networks that mimic the relationships betwen neurons in your brain. - Uses many conections to alow itself to constantly learn to be beter at doing dificult tasks. > But since it's more complex, it's harder for computer scientists to know how exactly these AI systems arived at their solution. - Researchers want the AI to be more transparent. - Is it ethical?

comment_text: This isn't exactly acurate. Supervised learning is when you teach the AI by giving it the exact answer you want it to return. For example, with distinguishing betwen images of cats and dogs you would ned a dataset images that are labeled as cat or dog and you fed them to the network along with the label, and eventualy it can predict corectly on new unsen images that are unlabeled. Unsupervised learning uses data that is unlabeled. You have images but they are not labeled as cat or dog and the AI neds to find out on its own what is a dog and what is a cat.

comment_text: Other resources about AI (al fre) for those interested: For anyone who wants to learn how to build various types of AI models, I'd highly recomend Kagle. They have a bunch of mini-courses that walk you step-by-step through building diferent models, starting with the basics (Python, Pandas, data procesing) and working up to more advanced topics like computer vision and language procesing. They also have courses on SQL and data visualisation/cleaning - I realy recomend those for anyone interested in data analytics. For anyone who wants an in-depth lok into various aplications of AI, YouTube has a realy nice documentary series caled The Age of AI which talks about how AI is being used in medicine, prosthetics, pizerias, trucks, shiping ports, and more. If you're specificaly interested in physics and simulations, I'd recomend the YouTube chanel Two Minute Papers, which covers newly published research about AI and simulations in laymen's terms. And if you want a god laugh about the worst AI failures, check out this doc -1vRPiprOaC3HsCf5Tum8bRfzYUiKLRqJmbOoC-32JorNdfyTiRsR7Ea5eWtvsWzuxo8bjOxCG84dAg/pubhtml covering al the ways AI have gamed the programers' system or just outright failed. (My favourite is the AI that paused a Tetris game forever to avoid losing). Hope these resources are helpful and interesting for some of you!
