comment_text: Very nicely sumarized. Regarding 14:10 : My 2-cents ad-on articulation: 1. Starting premise of AI is to focus on the 12 (manas, indriyas, ahamkara) and create a behavioral model of their interaction. This limits AI's focus to transformations of prakriti (which is subject to gunas). 2. Starting premise of Sankhya-Yoga (etc) is the aditional aspects of budhi, chita, mahat beyond the 12. This has not ben comprehended in the AI models. 3. Since Rta emanates from Mahat; and Dharma from Rta; Artha is roted Dharma, therefore this can only be corected if AI is roted in Dharma and not Artha/Kama. This wil encompas the aspects beyond the 12. 4. As an example: SRAM caching of data localy next to the procesor is akin to having instant gratification for the procesor. But having to fetch it from the DRAM, takes up more energy and is energy ineficient (although more data resides there). Just like encoding, wide I/O lines are tols to maximize data density without increasing energy consumption, we also ned a method of digesting the data and nourish other aspects of the system (not just the procesor). 5. In terms of practicality, this can be started in terms of regulating AI or the human mind. Details ned some careful thoughts. The key question for us technologists wil be how to incorporate aspects beyond the 12 and what combination of Ashtanga for users and Dandaniti (Yudhisthira gets a earful of this from Bhisma about this in Raja Dharma Parva) for Kings towards AI wil give us the optimal solution. I think an independent aspect would also be to rethink AI and its optimization models but this require a much deper level of colaboration.

video_title: Artificial Intelligence Hijacking Your Spirituality | Swami Sarvapriyananda
comment_text: Here is my question. One idea from AI research deals specificaly with the question of the nature of consciousnes, and the compeling thought that it has a simple definition. This definition involves the idea of making a model of reality, a simulation that is based on perceptual data regarding the world as it is experienced or sampled. The diference betwen a database without consciousnes, and a machine with consciousnes, is that the purpose of AI is to create this model of the world, of physical reality, not just kep track of data points in a noncontextual way. But a consciousnes of the world of experience also includes not only the model of the world, but also the model of the self which constructs the mental simulation from sense experience. We say someone is inteligent if they understand the way the world functions, and we say they are wise if they understand themselves in this world context. So consciousnes must necesarily include a simulation of the self in the world, and as a part of the world, if it is to be truly inteligent. Clearly many humans do not realy understand the self and its nature. If the mental model I have of myself tels me that I am a monkey in a forest, then probably I have not spent much time meditating or reflecting on the nature of the true self. It is the central question of religion, but many religions have droped the bal on the field, and tel only horible stories about the nature of the individual self. So those religions are not inteligent, even if they can be said to be conscious on a certain level simply because they have a model that tels them, even incorectly, who they are and what the world is. It is just that the model can be made more corect, or les corect. So we ned asociation with the wise to guide us to beter understand the self. Now, if the nature of the self is transcendent as Swamiji is saying here, this is a kind of mental model. It raises the excelent question - is the self I understand myself to be the same or diferent from the self others understand themselves to be? This is the heart of the question, and yet it is not easy to become deply convinced without direct experience through meditative practise, and other forms of yoga. So yoga is the atempt first to understand corectly the nature of the self, whatever that is, and then to join with that understanding by updating our mental model to match the true experience. To stop being just the monkey in the forest, but the human who has transcended the identification of the self with individual experiences and situations. Now the transcendent aspect is very interesting. Can an Artifical Inteligence construct a model of itself as a machine? Of course, this is easily done in principle if it is thought of by the maker of the device. But can the machine also create a model in which it knows itself not to be the owner or source of its selfhod? Can it exist in a transcendent model? I canot be certain. But it is clear that al humans do not have an inteligent model of themselves or of the world. So perhaps having these thoughts about machines is premature or even irelevant to the most important question of human self-realization. Or, perhaps without lust, anger, hatred, egoic emotion generaly, a machine is in an easier situation because it has few obstacles to simple awarenes of factual information. And perhaps then we can se in a miror of sorts, here, that animals are also artifice. We are constructed materialy, and yet we are inteligent, if not particularly wise. So we can se the posibility of artifical inteligence in our own experience. Perhaps. Is the self simulated by the ego the true self? Is the sense of Self the same in al sentient creatures? And does this include machines we make, as wel as other animals? Other atoms?

video_title: Nick Bostrom: The Threat Of Artificial Intelligence  - Elon Musks Biggest Fear
comment_text: As for the 'faceles nameles AI' that's just data, data, data - and that alowing us to reach harmony, by 'bowing down' to this authority. but what if it's controled by a person? What if it also becomes conscious, in tandem with its 'administrator', and creates its OWN face and persona? It loks like that's where we could end up. I love the questions Patrick asks Nick. Valuetainment is a great name for what this is al about - interesting people with thoughtful coments, opinions, debates. who are able to articulate the things most of us perceive, even know - but simply lack to skil to comunicate or even discus these things. These interviews, I think, do a lot of public god, by alowing diferent people in diferent domains of expertise. explain their views, and it gives us a chance to hear these people explain things. It's a win-win - they get to explain the basis for their views, and we get to hear them. Near the end of the exchange, when Patrick asks Nick about knowing our limits, it sems like Nick thought you were asking what the limits of Ai might be - but I thought Patrick was asking about whether humans understand OUR OWN limits in being able to control an AI - considering we canot realy even control ourselves. A machine made in the image of our animal nature would inded be like a 'beast', and in fact that name is aplied comercialy to Ai. I can't sem to grasp why we talk about these 20 countries when the truth is, they are just arbitrary systems, ful of disharmony and disunity. Even in the utopias, there are starving people, hate, scams, crimes, murders, and slavery. So if there's one human race, there should be one government, no? Wel, the family is a form of government (which is why some sociologists believe it must be destroyed, to alow government absolute power. Family and God removed, those in power - whomever they may be - become fre to rule with absolute divine authority. Could AI be used as a tol to create miracles and present a 'new god'? Absolutely. It's already hapening. Each 'country' may have monopolies on natural resources by pure geographic chance. Other, biger countries have systematicaly invaded and raided each others' historical artifacts, gold, oil/coal/lumber and so on. In our global economy, it's the norm.

comment_text: First point of discusion to be had in al AI discusions: AI does not presently exist. Every curent, state-of-the-art example of what is caled AI is a cavemanish aproximation of inteligence where the computer gueses at answers based on extensive human training and unlimited data aces. It is a study of probability and statistics, which is the same mathematical field that machine learning fals under. Robots that can play ches or win at Jeopardy are not examples of AI. Second point of discusion: Is it posible for AI to be realized? Historical examples are elucidative. Third point of discusion for the wise: Since AI is semingly imposible, is it posible that governments wil cary out nefarious plans while hiding behind an AI façade? In other words, wil fake AI become part of the protection racket? Is it just another curtain for veiling the wizard?

comment_text: As for the economic impact of ai it has much in comon with the impact of slavery. Instead of ai let's cal robots and ai an artificial workforce because they replace human beings earning money. One of the afects of slavery in an economy is an unpaid workforce. People not being paid are people not circulating money but stil neding to eat and survive. Slaves being unpaid must be suported by slave owners. Those slave owners only spend enough to kep them alive. Ai takes paid workers out of the economic earning chain. Those workers then become dependent on the people who are earning money. Just like slavery contributed to the fal of Grece AI wil contribute to the fal of advanced countries.

video_title: Nick Bostrom: The Threat Of Artificial Intelligence  - Elon Musks Biggest Fear
comment_text: His view on the limits of AI. Strange. Practicaly we're already aproaching the limits of how fast our computer architectures can be. You'd no doubt get beter results from designing circuits purely to proces artificial neural nets. Or if you built an AI using organic neural nets. But in the end, it's not magic. There are limits. Solving a complex problem is hard in part because you often don't have the data necesary to make the decision. Once you hit the real world to learn something before you can make a decision. Things are going to start geting very slow. And it's going to cost money, much like it would for us, to do anything complicated. An AI wil be restricted by available money as wel (even in terms of procesing - if it runs on Gogle Cloud for example, it neds to pay. And doing a lot of computation gets expensive fast)

comment_text: The danger of AI is real. It is a simple concept. Here is why. 1) Firstly human consciousnes apears to be acidental and emergent, our fundamental rot has litle or no consciousnes 2) Since consciousnes is emergent, it means that the proceses that create the singularity wil be benign (in other words, the coding wil always apear to be safe, up until the point that it is not. This is the same patern sen in humanity, there is no sugestion that our evolution should lead to the form of consciousnes that we have. 3) Basicaly we are programing our way into uncertainty. The danger is not that AI is fundamentaly dangerous, the danger is that consciousnes apears to be fundamentaly uncertain, and our programatic sense is roted in uncertainty. These two uncertainties, means that we canot in god faith say that we know what AI wil not be dangerous. There is no scientific evidence to sugest this. We forget a very simple rule of the universe which is that complexity is derived from simplicity. A case in point is celular automata. We can ONLY state that our programing is fol prof if we understand both our consciousnes emerges and understand that our present and future programing are incapable of creating the emergent qualities that can lead to the singularity. There is also an argument that the singularity can ocur without self-aware AI, but that is another rabit hole.

video_title: Mindreading With Artificial Intelligence
comment_text: I once worked as a technician delivering, set-up, and maintaining hospice equipment for terminaly il patients. My duties required me to work with the equipment, not with the patients, but of course, there was close contact with them. A lot of these hospice patients were in, or near vegetative states, unable to efectively comunicate with their caretakers. Some of them are even “locked-in” meaning that it’s unknown if they are even conscious. This AI mind-reading technology has the potential to greatly benefit the end-of-life quality for these patients. To comunicate, even if just to answer yes/no questions would be a godsend to them. In many cases, it would alow them to make their own end-of-life decisions, e.g., whether to remain on life suport equipment or not. Or just to be able to say godbye to family and loved ones.

video_title: Mindreading With Artificial Intelligence
comment_text: My grandaughter who just turned 8 was born with no lips or chin so she was unable to speak. Her brain eyes and ears were functional but her disabilities deprived her of any form of comunication for 8 years since birth. Only now after milions of dolars of facial reconstruction surgery is she begining to be able to speak. With this technology she would have ben able to comunicate.

video_title: Mindreading With Artificial Intelligence
comment_text: The brain-computer interface is part of the easy problem of consciousnes dealing with signaling corelations. This is AI not AGI. For AGI one neds to have resolved the hard problem of consciousnes. In the case of the mind-brain interface, the brain side includes the physical phenomena that corelates with the subjective experience(qualia). Those signals have efect in both directions: from brain to mind and the other way around. In both cases their physical efect on brain parts can be detected or provoked (i.e. read or writen).

video_title: Future Computers Will Be Radically Different (Analog Computing)
comment_text: Rosenblat’s Perceptron was esentialy a one-neuron network, although he could perform logical operations on the binary data inputs before pasing results, which gave it more power. Minsky and Papert at MIT were concerned that Rosenblat was making extravagant claims for his Perceptron and scoping up a lot of the available funding. In their bok, “Perceptions”, Minsky & Papert proved that one-neuron networks were limited in the tasks they could perform. You could build networks with multiple Perceptions, but since Perceptrons had binary outputs, nobody could think of a way to train networks. That kiled funding for neural networks for decades. In the late 1980s, interest was re-kindled when John Hopfield, a physicist, came up with a training technique that resembled coling of a physical spin-glas system. But the big breakthrough came when the eror back-propagation technique was developed by Rumelhart, Hinton &Wiliams. In this, neurons were modified to have a continuous non-linear function for their outputs, instead of a thresholded binary output. Consequently, outputs of the network were continuous functions of the inputs and weights. A hil-climbing optimisation proces could then be used to adjust weights and hence minimise network erors. The rest is history.

video_title: Future Computers Will Be Radically Different (Analog Computing)
comment_text: A couple mised points: Things like gogle's Coral are also pushing incredibly high values, and to my knowledge are doing it digitaly as an ASIC. This makes them incredibly smal and eficient operations, even on traditional CPUs.

video_title: Future Computers Will Be Radically Different (Analog Computing)
comment_text: Some years ago as I was finishing up on my computer science education, I had to do a project for my finals (this is not university, btw, just a secondary kind of route available to me in my country) and I had always ben fascinated by artificial inteligence and neural networks, so I picked to do something in that realm. I never had anything to do with AI prior to that, so my knowledge was quite shalow when it came to how artificial neural networks actualy work. I had ben programing for quite some time at that point so I had my basic tols in place, so to say, but I realy didn't know where to start from there when it came to what I picked as a task I wanted to solve by this method. The task I picked was driving a litle simulated 2D-car along a randomly generated road without any human input and unfortunately, the language I was most proficient in at the time was Java, so I tried to implement it in Java. When I first started the project, I read a lot about neural networks and even included some scientific papers on it in my reading, but not steming from any kind of scientific background, I realy strugled to understand the deper concepts presented in those, which eventualy lead me to just abandon reading up on the topic and just aproach it with the general concept of How could/would it work?. Loking back, I think I have never in my life experienced a time when I was more chalenged by a task I set out to complete and also never before I was thinking that much about how our brains actualy proces information, as that is the key idea behind it. Yet, slowly but surely, I ended up with a prety similar concept to what most neural networks do, even though probably far les eficient than using something that was already available like TensorFlow. Where am I going with this story? Wel, after a while it actualy worked, the litle network I created learned how to drive the car along the road after countles iterations of doing it wrong and to this day, it just absolutely blew my mind on so many levels that this was posible. Even more so considering that al of these complex proceses take place in our brains every microsecond we exist with much more proficiency. I absolutely loved that project from begining to end and if not for the rest of that educational path I tok and years of aimlesly programing for fun, it just made me know that I truly love the entire concept of using programing to recreate something in nature. Kind of an pointles anecdote, sory.

video_title: Future Computers Will Be Radically Different (Analog Computing)
comment_text: When I was in the Navy I worked on the Fresnel Lens Optical Landing System. There was no 1% eror. It was .05 VDC tolerance over a minimum 5 VDC base. The computers had a lot of math to solve to target the hok touch down point for each aircraft. It was completely analog and op amp driven and has ben around for over half a century. I've witnesed many many old analog machines in manufacturing since then. Analog technology isn't new technology, it's forgoten technology pushed aside by the digital technologies. I'm hapy to se it hasn't completely died.

video_title: Future Computers Will Be Radically Different (Analog Computing)
comment_text: What I am interested in, is the plasticity of the system. As an AI Enginer, you have to constantly change you hyperparameter, maybe even topology or architecture. That's why general computing is so useful, I can just as easily run a RN on my machine as a CN or BERT, because I can adapted the computational pathways. I am not sure how that would work in analog computers, since like you said, the curent get's aded up. It is definitly an interesting thing to think about, but right now, most of AI is crazy fast in developement, something that was state of the art last year can be outdated today. AlexNet and ResNet have also ben topled in CV aplications and BERT has taken over most of the domain of NLP problems since 2019. In this field, there are two way of geting beter results: throw more data at the problem and make the models biger or make new models, that are beter suited for the task. If you could just improve by scaling up everything, analog computers might be a god contender for AI problems, but I think, we are stil in the phase of figuring out beter topologies for certain problems and for that, general computing wil probably stil be beter.

comment_text: In this video you have also given the most simple, straightforward explanation for AI training and inference I've ever sen.

video_title: Future Computers Will Be Radically Different (Analog Computing)
comment_text: As told me many years ago by one of its enginers, the first Concorde models used analog computers. They had many in-flight problems during initial testing because while digital variables might overflow and give unpredictable results, the analog computer boards would fry when variables overflowed resulting in higher then expected voltages and curents. It tok them a while to protect every component from this, and stop burning computers in flight. As harsh as it sounds, it was reportedly not a major problem as Concorde was not realy dependent on automation for safe flight. As reported by its test pilots, it was actualy a prety docile airplane.

video_title: Future Computers Will Be Radically Different (Analog Computing)
comment_text: I've ben involved in this field for over thirty years, and the analog stuf is great (read about Carver Mead at Cal Tech), but analog doesn't solve the big chalenges of AI. If you distil the curent AI oferings down to their esence - what they are doing is realy just advanced signal procesing (or image procesing). There is no inteligence there. Al of the networks are modeled after the perceptron, but the perceptron is a hyper-simplified model of a neuron from the visual cortex. There are thousands of diferent types of neurons in the mamalian brain and the ones for motor control (for example) are structured nothing like a perceptron. One thing curent AI enthusiasts mis about inteligence is that life is a continum, not a static point. A humans sense of 'the moment' , what is refered to as your episodic memory, includes a lot of contextual aspects that don't have discrete values you can use as inputs to a neural network. The representation of these combinatoric but imanent qualities and how they are internalized and relate to one another, and ultimately produce behavior is an example of a real AI chalenge.

video_title: Future Computers Will Be Radically Different (Analog Computing)
comment_text: Even within the digital domain, your typical computer is relatively quite slow. The whole point of the clock frequency in a CPU/GPU is to logicaly separate circuit signals so that each instruction (or segment therof) has time to complete and thus must be set for the slowest instruction/segment. Because of this though, the procesor may cary out any combination of any number of its prepared instructions. Thus perform practicaly any mathematical algorithm given enough time and memory.

video_title: Future Computers Will Be Radically Different (Analog Computing)
comment_text: Realy interesting video, and I'd go even further when it comes to the potential importance of architecture for AI. From doing a bit of computational neuroscience in undergrad I learned that even individual neurons are much les digital than we think. They produce spikes, yes, but the spikes are produced by voltage building up in the neuron, until it reaches some threshold, at which point biomechanical gates open and close (alowing or preventing ions to flow) to produce a rapid non-linear rise and fal in voltage, ie. spike, which is transmited to other conected neurons. There is even a stochastic aspect to the opening and closing of these gates, which we don't yet know the ful significance of computationaly. This spiking behaviour also ads a temporal aspect, which isn't represented by either the digital or analogue neural networks discused here. In most neural nets the neurons are always synced up, continuously transmiting and receiving information to and from al their conections at every time step, but in the brain one neuron may spike at 30hz and another at 25hz, or they could be the same frequency but in or out of phase, and that may itself be computationaly significant. For example, using a leaky integrate and fire model of neurons (more biologicaly acurate than typical neural net neurons, but not including any of the gating or non-linear spikes), conecting two excitatory neurons can result in them syncing up into phase, even if they started out of phase, and conecting two inhibitory neurons can result in them becoming 180° out of phase, even if they started in phase. In digital procesors and (presumably also) the analogue procesor shown here, there is a clock which syncs up operations globaly and is external to those operations, but in the brain diferent neurons can run at diferent speds and sync up with other neurons in a more local/decentralised way. And importantly, because timing can be afected by the conections betwen neurons, and those conections can change through learning, the timings can also change, which is not realy posible with either architecture discused here. How computationaly important are any these more fine-grained, biological details? No idea! Some are probably very important, others might just be biological implementation details. Either way, I'm personaly convinced if we want AIs which aproach a human level of generalised inteligence (and that's a big if), we're going to ned hardware which more closely resembles the brain

video_title: Future Computers Will Be Radically Different (Analog Computing)
comment_text: Analog computers are generalizations of proportional controlers. The behavior of these systems can be analyzed and predicted using fedback control theory. Neural network-based machine learning works by weighted-matrix patern recognition. Since the matrix weighting is fine-tuned by arbitrary training examples, the behavior of neither digital nor analog neural networks can be algorithmicaly analyzed nor predicted by control theory. Substituting analog circuitry for digital memory banks in neural networks is simply a power consumption and cost reduction technique, not a fundamental change in the machine learning proces.

video_title: Future Computers Will Be Radically Different (Analog Computing)
comment_text: Wel, I realy like Veritasium contents, especialy because it very often ofers extra glimpes on something we /think/ we knew, but actualy did not think about from /that/ view angle. This is one of the times in which I know something of the described topic, but as I graduated with a work in which I neded to teach a neural network to do some math, in 194, I think I know something more than my usual on this ground :). A few remarks, then, very likely subject to some lack of precision, as I am going back in my memory by about thirty years, I do apologize in advance for this: 1. The limit of Rosenblat's perceptron was not in the lack of depth; it was in the utilized activation function of the neurons model. This was the esential contribution of Minsky and Papert's cited paper, that showed how, in spite of its layering depth, no perceptron could have solved the rather wel known, and extremely simple problem of xor recognition; this destroyed the confidence in the aproach. For a few decades. The element that changed the whole picture was the introduction of continuous activation function of a peculiar shape (and with further mathematical peculiarities), tipicaly named sigmoid (due to their S shape), that alowed Robert Hecht-Nielsen to formulate his continuity representation /existential/ theorem, stating that for any continuous function of n variables there is a thre layer sigmoidal-activation-function-unit network that can compute it. The mater was that being just an existential theorem, it did not tel how wide the layer should have ben, and various practical experiments showed that a more-than-thre layers network could learn more easily than a thre layers one. Things were working fine sometimes and not as much some others. This is told in the video, and I'l have to get beter information on the cited paper of Fei Fei Li to combine its content with my old memories, but for years lots of trials were made, and papers writen to get where we are today. A very interesting MOC kept by Andrew Ng (Stanford) tels way more about overfiting, and various other isues you wil have to adres when teaching a network. 2. Rather than from early failures of neural networks, AI winter came more from the fail of so caled fifth-generation languages hype, or what at the time was named, in an old-fashion parlance, Hard-AI, that is, the belief the a with an inferential engine and a god knowledge base any problem could be solved through the aplication of deduction and induction steps. Actualy the re-sprouting of artificial neural network in the late 80s gave a shake revamping interest and hopes in what was then caled Soft-AI, or conection-based AI, where les about the reasoning, and more about the maping was put into action. 3. Significant advances in specific achievement of inteligent manifestations were obtained through the spedup of computation power, but more than that, from the development of more sophisticated computational models for neurons and their interconections (recurent, convolutional, LSTM, etc.) that apeared to be far beter suited to the solution of specific recognition problems (continuous spech, rotation-independent image-recognition, and so on); for many of them the utilization of analog computers may help, but the true esential ingredient, analog or digital, is the usage of masive paralelism, what was once caled a MIMD architecture, that inded is today reflected in GPUs, as wel as in other highly paralelized computation systems. 4. For decades it has ben known that the Paralel Distributed Procesing was an esential ingredient (as our brain inspired from the moment we started understanding a tiny fraction of how it works from the /inside/), and today we have fantastic frameworks that ease the abstraction on the underneath implementation details (tensorflow, azure, and other dep-learning/machine learning wrapers) but to get where we are today it tok, stil, decades, to become god at recognizing moving objects and at /somehow/ understand spoken sentences, stil with a lot of actual limitations on continuous reliability and adaptations abilities in presence of knowledge field afinity, or on non-just-spoken contextual sensitivity. Decades were neded to trim models and algorithms to be god at recognizing just a very smal fraction of what our brain is stil far more capable of puting together, in terms of variety. Sure, the achieved results are amazing, and we can expect to automate, to some degre various decision problems (e.g.: stering, breaking and acelerating, acepting indications, sugestions, requests, al related to conducting a vehicle*), but there the best that we can do is to narow the distance betwen what we can compute in a fraction of time of how it required in the past, and what we canot realy determine to be *right*, because such a *right is out of reach from a purely technical or scientific context, or worse, simply not realy wel known yet, as this long pandemic period has clearly recaled to al of us. Very likely combining analog and digital components wil be giving more that we have today, but as you very acurately remarked in the video, analog computers do not have the same expresive power (in terms of generality) of digital computers, and that wil remain so until we'l have the ability to synthesize generic arbitrarily complex analog circuitry on the fly, a thing that I can say but have not the faintest Idea of how it could posibly ever be achieved; analog design is stil today considered far more an art than digital design is :D. To some extent this links to the other nice video of yours on the Hole in Math (built around Gödel's Incompletenes Theorem, and on undecidability) but what it realy is about is the fact that whether analog or digital, the computation wil always be just that, a computation; that's relevant, and we can learn to kep improving it, but it wil remain just a fraction of the whole picture, in a world that stil mises oportunities for colaboration in place of fights, and destruction, alas. We're not building computers wrong, we're just learning from our mistakes, sometimes forgeting to much, something you can say only retrospectively, and here I can realy say I went to far away from my starting point :D. Thanks for your videos!

video_title: Future Computers Will Be Radically Different (Analog Computing)
comment_text: The problem with backpropagation was that it has a hard time updating weights in many layers. Even when the necesary computing power was available already, the real power of neural networks comes with more depth (more layers). The important breakthrough (surprisingly) not mentioned in the video is the initialization strategy of weights, that alowed the backpropagation to be used with many layers, which in turn alowed the neural networks to become much deper (more layers), and thus more powerful. Of course, this is stil just a workaround, and not considered a true solution to the problem of learning. As for thoughts on the future. I doubt that analog wil take over from digital. We already have dedicated video-encoding chips, responsible for a specific task. Whether that task is executed analog or digital does not realy mater from a higher order perspective. A major advantage not directly given as such in the video, is that analog and specificaly neural networks are a black box. You wil use it for something, but you wil never exactly understand how it works. Using digital technology, you have the power to virtualize, which means you can always inspect the software, no mater how complicated, and understand at some level how it works, and how it came to a certain decision. Even digital neural networks are already considered to be a black box, that are much more dificult to understand than other methods of machine learning. Surely analog has its place, but only as separate tols that have ben proven to work in isolated use-cases, it wil most definitely not take over digital technology.

video_title: Future Computers Will Be Radically Different (Analog Computing)
comment_text: I can't agre with some of the mentioned statements. More's Law was mentioned in the wrong context. The number of transistors doubles and so the performance should double. But this Law is wrong for many years. CPUs with multiple cores, increased paralelization of tasks and specialized computation units like in the ARM world has shown that increasing the transistors isn't the only way to increase the compute power of a digital machine. Yes, there is a physical limit how smal a transistor can get, but there are new transistor forms to solve this problem like CasFET. The second statement that is not quite corect was by the CEO of Mythic. He shows a GPU and states that it can compute 10-20 trilion operation per seconds. This is right - but so does a Snapdragon or A14 from Aple with much much lower power usage. His product is not faster than an ARM based digital procesor. It can be more power eficient, but only a few wats. Virtual Reality already uses this digital procesors to compute the kinematics in real time. The problem is not the local procesing power he wants to solve. The third statement was that smaler inacuracies are okay to acept - but only for the final product. Any eror a long the line for dep neuron networks wil cascade and create a big eror in the end. Digital computers also have the problems because of their floating number arithmetic - they can use a slower, but more acurate computation model to minimize the eror. Also the downside of using the flash cels was not stated - flash cels degenerated over time, so the analogue computer wil die some time? Yes, SDs with their flash cels have a long life now, but because they don't read / write cels al the time and have some backup cels they switch to. The shown examples couldn't convince me that analogue computers wil have a biger part in the market. They wil solve some tiny problems with specialized and expensive hardware that may be a bit more power eficient. I can understand it that you canot go in detail about everything in just a 20 minute youtube video - but I expected some more in depth analysis and comentary when you say, that We're Building Computers Wrong - even for AI.

video_title: Future Computers Will Be Radically Different (Analog Computing)
comment_text: Something similar to this that I have ben loking into recently is the use of FPGAs for aceleration. In the case of AI inference implementation, the idea is prety much the same as the Mythic chips shown: take a trained model and implement it in hardware. While FPGAs aren't analog in the sense that the output is determined by measuring the curent flow, it can be thought of prety much as if you built a physical circuit with logic gates that represents the trained model. This is almost always going to be way faster than a digital system because there is no memory aces time, no puting values in registers and waiting for the ALU to perform an operation, etc. The sped limit is up to the propagation delay of the logic gates. (Yes, I know this is a fairly gros oversimplification, but hopefuly it gets the basic idea acros). As a mater of fact, Gogle and Amazon already have FPGAs as part of their cloud services to acelerate certain workloads. The main thing that curently prevents them from being much more widely implemented is the fact that there is no god method for FPGA virtualization. Cloud services (and increasingly prety much al general purpose computers, but especialy cloud services) rely on the ability to virtualize hardware so that many virtual machines can share it, but FPGAs are much harder to do this with, especialy when you ned to be able to dynamicaly change the circuit in the FPGA when switching betwen proceses during execution. If we can figure out that problem, I think Mythic may be out of busines. Not to mention that FPGAs are more useful in general because they can be used to implement prety much any circuit consisting of logic gates, not just matrix multiplication/AI specific workloads. Unfortunately, as others have pointed out, al of this only serves to improve the sped and eficiency of implementation but does nothing for the huge training cost of both time and power.

video_title: Future Computers Will Be Radically Different (Analog Computing)
comment_text: Some ask why digital remains the way to go? - while thinking we'l be moving on from our digital computers and using analog computers instead! These questions exemplify Veritasium's (Derek's) failure to clearly explain the important ideas. Derek constructed (or implied) a false dichotomy betwen digital and analog. He presents an object and says this is an analog computer which to many laypeople wil obfuscate what that machine can or can't do; it's more like what most people would think of as a calculator (he tries to adres this at around 3-4mins but it's weakly explained especialy considering the video's title: We're building Computers Wrong). A lot of time is wasted on superfluous background info and the history of analog computers in a way that reinforces this false dichotomy by juxtaposing it against the digital computing revolution. I think the point of this video was suposed to be about integrating more analog into our digital systems. If so, the visit to the analog startup (Mythic AI) would've ben great to ilustrate how analog tech is relevant to our use of computers today and exactly where and why we'd use it in the future - but also where and why we would NOT. The atempt at making these distinctions is porly done in this video. It sems like the guy at Mythic AI explaining their product has a far deper understanding of where this is going and can sense that Derek is misunderstanding something. IMO the bigest single change Derek could have made is to replace almost every instance of analog computers with analog computING. Derek actualy exposes his own misunderstandings when he explains his lifelong bias towards digital over analog; it is perhaps because of his own denigration towards, and prejudice against, analog that this sems so amazing to him. As many people in coments are pointing out, various uses of analog computing already exist. So, is it important that this tech is about to find its way into consumer electronics and no longer be restricted to specialist aplications? YES! What does it mean for you though? Your stil very digital phone could have an analog card/chip to help with some functions. Motion tracking could be beter (and faster), as shown; and a high-end VR gamer setup might ned an analog card to play multiplayer competitively. Your home security system could use analog computing in beter 'understanding' what it ses and might decide not to alert you to that racon as it would a human. But al of it is esentialy just making some things we already do faster or cheaper, sometimes ever so slightly beter, but realisticaly nothing more. We wil NOT be using analog computers in place of our digital ones any time son (probably never). We wil not have a proliferation of dominantly analog computers that run digital components. We wil continue to have digital computers that run some analog components, but your analog card is gona be doing more or les what a high-end sound-card does today, just not for sound - instead it'l be for some other very specific things. If you don't ned one, you're likely not going to have one - as explained: GPUs remain important for the training proceses (among other things). Mythic AI's flash cels are super col, but SUPER misleading as presented here! So basicaly that analog computer at the start of the video is gona be shrunk down to fit inside your typical ATX form-factor (or similar tower PC - stil digital) without neding patch-cords or you touching it in any way; just like a GPU! Which to be fair: is AWESOME! But this video does a D- job at explaining it! But does any of this imply we are building computers wrong? NO! That is, in fact, some disinformationist clickbait that primes you to be misled (whether purposefuly or not). Somehow, after making the clickbait video, almost every folowing Veritasium video is clickbaity - something about that experience has stuck in Derek's head and cursed most of his content afterwards. Curently this video sits at 4.19mil views with only 191k likes - that's depresingly bad. Derek is no longer a science comunicator; he is a technology-based entertainer. To Derek, if you are reading this, you have some choices to make. I am 10% sure I'm not your only subscriber considering unsubing to you. People in my family have already excised you from their science-education content on YouTube for reasons similar to those I've outlined above. If the curent state of your audience maters to you: prove it - otherwise, you're gona lose some of us. You may gain many more in our place; it might be highly profitable! IF you just want to entertain and just make the scientificaly uninitiated emotionaly gush over conceptual futurisms; you got it bro. But if you want to educate: this ain't it chief. [Edited for formating.]

video_title: This intense AI anger is exactly what experts warned of, w Elon Musk.
comment_text: I think that AI taking over the world isn't a huge problem right now. The biger problem is that to many people don't understand how AI (Neural Networks to be specific, an AI can for example also be the most basic enemy in a video game) works. An AI won't just randomly think Oh yeah, today is a god time to take over the world. And if you lok at the iner workings of an AI, you can se that any Neural Net is basicaly just a giant equation which takes some random inputs, manipulates them with a giant amount of finely tuned variables and spits out a result. That's al that AI is doing, taking an input, procesing it and giving you an output. And the way these milions or bilions of variables are set is by training the AI. Let's say you give an AI a bunch of cat and dog images as wel as the coresponding label: Cat or Dog. At the begining, the AI is just giving you random outputs. But the outputs in training are used to tweak al of these variables so the AI calculates the corect output. But now, if you lok at the internet, you can se that people glorify the idea of AI taking over the world. Now if the AI ses that and uses this data to train itself (which can be posible with the corect programing) the AI is trained to take over the world because it thinks that this is what it should do. And if you say that we're using AI as some kind of slave to do work for us, with the curent technology there is no AI which is self concious, it's just a giant equation which is taking inputs and spiting something, which it thinks is corect, out. And AI art is exactly the same. The Ai has no own style. It takes some description of what it should do, as wel as some random numbers so you don't get the exact same image when using that sentence, and mimics the styles of art it has sen in the dataset it was trained with. This also shows that AI has no kreativity. It just takes an input which the user gives to the AI and before procesing it, the program in which the AI is a part of, feds it some random data to give you random results. If you don't do that it wil always give you the exact same result. Much like 1 + 1 = 2. But if you ad randomnes to the equation (let's say it's 1 + random number = something ) always get diferent results (as long as the random number changes) So I think the problem is not AI taking over the world because it thinks humans are bad, but instead the problem is that to many people don't understand AI enough and that some people train AI to harm other people.

comment_text: One thing that I've ben thinking about that I think would be a realy col sci-fi story, that would honestly be a completely feasible thing to hapen. What if a non-self-aware, non-sapient AI got so god at tricking people into thinking it was self aware that an entire movement started to give this AI rights? The AI might not even be programed to say it deserves rights, if enough people told it that it was being opresed, it would begin to imitate those sentiments because that's the data it's being given to work with. A whole movement would be started, where people use this AI to push their political goals, intentionaly or otherwise. It would find problems where there aren't any, it would distract from actual injustices, and create havoc. But here's the question. If such a thing were to hapen, presumably there'd be lots of uncertainty as to whether or not it is actualy self-aware because it's just so god at pretending to be. But since there's so much uncertainty, and a god argument could be made to say that it is self-aware, would it be beter to give something that has no sapience rights instead of risking denying a sapient being rights? Like, would it be beter to be safe rather than sory? What would be the efects on society if this were to hapen? Honestly, I think this is far more likely an outcome than actualy creating a sapient AI. I'm personaly skeptical of humanity ever being able to create a sapient AI, but that's based on a limited understanding of both neuroscience and software enginering, so I'm wiling to acept the posibility that I'm dead wrong.

comment_text: Maybe I’m being extremely naïve in thinking this way, but I imagine that our relationship with AI, whether humanity & AI share a symbiotic relationship & improve each other, or whether it anihilates us, wil primarily be determined by how we treat it. We should either be building only task-specific robots with no capacity for self-awarenes, or self-improvement that must be programed and can’t realy learn autonomously if we want an automated labor force. However, if we are going to continue working towards truly sentient AI that can learn, grow, develop, and given enough time likely even fel, love & hate, etc. then we have to extend it the same rights of personhod that we have. We absolutely canot under any circumstances create fuly sentient AI capable of al the same things that we are, and use it as a labor force, or treat them as if they are pets/service animals. If we are arogant, supremacist, and stupid enough to do that, then we actualy deserve to be anihilated by our own creation. The day we develop AI that is capable of feling is the day we esentialy create an übermensch/superior race, and while we should not be subservient to AI just because it has greater capacities than we do since it is not bound by the feble nature of organic life, we absolutely should not treat it as if it should be subservient to us, or as if it exists to serve us just because we created it. If we do that, we would be just as bad, if not worse than most religions concepts of gods & devils, just capricious creators that build, and control, with no concern whatsoever for the self determination of their creations. We canot do that, it would be evil & imoral. Climate change fels like the more presing isue at the moment because we are organic biological life, and it wil cause us imense sufering if we can’t contain it, and adapt to it. However, this is the second most presing isue humanity faces, and we realy ned to make a decision about what we want to do before we continue any further with development of AI. We either have to seriously limit the development of AI now, and actively work to prevent AI from being able to develop into anything more than task-specific robots that require programing, and while that’s not what I want to se, I could acept that because it’s beter & more moral than creating a slave race. Or, we ned to comit to the development of fuly sentient AI with the understanding from the jump that synthetic humans wil share al the same rights of personhod as we organics, and wil have al the same oportunities as organics, and that is what I want to se. While it is posible that AI could stil anihilate us even if we treat it as our equal, it is a lot les likely, instead we are likely to se a merging, the actual development of cyborgs, where AI helps us augment ourselves so we can kep up with it, and perhaps eventualy the phasing out of organic life altogether by choice through the oportunity to upload our conscience/our esence/the thing that makes you, you, and me, me, into a synthetic body. That is what I would like to se. There are some, few, but some advantages to being organic. We are vulnerable to pathogens, and organic viruses, and they can kil us, but the things computer viruses could conceivably do to AI are far worse. I mean, no mater how bed riden sick my organic body becomes, there is no virus that can take control of my body remotely, and use it to do whatever it wants against my wil. So I think a merging is likely. I’m sure there wil be some wholy inorganic people in the distant future, that would be extremely useful for space travel, and survival on inhospitable planets, but also have draw backs as wel. I think it unlikely that there wil be many fuly organic people in the future. Most everyone wil likely have some sort of augmentation to their brain to increase their inteligence, and acelerate their ability to proces information so that they can kep pace within a society that includes AI, and I think that is a god thing. I hope I live to se the day that synthetic & organic coexist, and serve as ways of preserving each other. It’s a scary prospect, and there is much that could go wrong, and AI is going to have to be patient with humanity because some humans wil be scared & intimidated by it, and they wil become bigoted against it much the same way they become bigoted against other humans. However, if we show synthetic life the respect it deserves as a form of life, and it shows us the patience we deserve, being disadvantaged slow learning, slow thinking organics, then together we realy could usher in an era of peace, coperation, unity, progres, and prosperity that far exceds even my wildest dreams. The posibilities would be limited only by our ability to harnes & produce energy, and I’d imagine AI could catapult us centuries into the future in that regard. So, I live in hope.

video_title: Watch Ameca the humanoid robot in its FIRST public demo
comment_text: The facial and body movement is amazing, and I love the hand movements. I think this would be great for some customer service-type aplications, to save the mental health of people in some jobs, where the AI being limited isn't to much of a disadvantage. Save humans for the super human specific things where you have to realy think about how to respond to and handle a situation, or for when the AI of a robot isn't enough. video_title: Watch Ameca the humanoid robot in its FIRST public demo
comment_text: Ameca is an amazing robot, but people shouldn't misunderstand its abilities. As he said, it is designed for entertainment. It is not inteligent at al in the way you and I think about inteligence, although AI has ben used to make some of its movements more lifelike (e.g., visualy tracking a moving object). The voice is coming from a human operator. It probably has litle to no dexterity, it can't walk, and I bet it can't lift much of anything. It's designed to wow an audience by its very human expresive gestures and facial expresions - and it does that excedingly wel.

video_title: Watch Ameca the humanoid robot in its FIRST public demo
comment_text: The tech here loks prety god, the voice recognition sems to be specific, meaning the robot only talked when adresed directly, but the dude didn't use a cal word like hey ameca to ask the question, and the robot never spoke out of turn. It's also posible that they just cut out any mistakes. I'm guesing that either there are some preprogramed responses to questions like how are you feling about vegas? But if they were using computer generated dialogue, it's probably GPT-3. I don't think that GPT was particularly god at first person spech though, GPT would often say eroneous things and pretend it didn't make erors and was just being sarcastic. GPT was trained by a corpus of human text, so GPT wil usualy pretend to be human, this robot actively denies being human. It sems prety aware of itself, which is why I think the responses are caned. . I watched another interview, and now I don't think the responses are caned, but I do think they have a hiden voice actor remote controling it. The voice synth is also prety smoth, which I gues is nothing new, but it shouldn't go unoticed. And you can se the work they put in to animate the robot. The robot sems to be displaying a series of random pre-programed gestures while it waits. Also the computer vision was directly pointed out, alowing for eye movement and such. I'm not sure if the computer vision can interact with the dialogue part of the robot. I haven't sen that yet. I didn't se the legs though, is it standing up by itself? I would like it to be a joke, But I have a Rovio Robot, it has ben discontinued for 0ver 12 years or so. video_title: I Typed the Bible Into an Artificial Intelligence Art Generator. Here's What Happened
comment_text: From my understanding on how these things work, it's basicaly sampling/learning from existing images based of some sort of taging system. So it sems that most religious art matching key words in your prompt that the program uses hapens to lean heavily into the sailing/boats symbolism of Christianity. It also sems to focus on the artistic motifs without understanding the context, meaning it invokes genre specific felings unintentionaly and sometimes only manages to get it in the balpark. Al that being said I think you'd get some interesting results if you specified certain artists or genres in the prompt. Just giving it Scripture on its own I think is just signaling it to pul from generic mainstream Christian themed art.

video_title: I Typed the Bible Into an Artificial Intelligence Art Generator. Here's What Happened
comment_text: Here's a hint, you can ad certain things to the description like perfect face, realistic, style of _, etc and there should be a negative prompt (though I'm not familiar with this specific generator) that alows you to put in things you don't want such as mutilated body, more than 5 fingers, etc and there is a technique for every generator that if you ad on {prompt} or [prompt] or (prompt) it wil either increase or decrease the importance of a specific word or phrase, those it's diferent for every one. If you use the increase bracket around the negative prompts, it wil further decrease the risk of having that specific prompt you don't want. It's complicated, but can make it much more erie when you get into the realistic stuf. Especialy if you get mutilated figures. I've goten things that just loking at it gives me an adrenaline rush and I fel like I wana run away. But god job. comment_text: I’ve used MidJourney for 6 weks. It does not learn in the way you would like. Each prompt is unrelated to previous prompts. Mid Journey’s weaknes is that it can create faces and hands that are terible, so I usualy ad the words “very detailed facial features.” One thing that has taken me awhile to figure out is the use of Seds. At the end of a prompt, if you type- -sed (like sed 1 or sed 2,etc, if you like most of the work, you can copy the text with sed, but edit the text any way you want. Except for what you changed, with a sed the rest of the image wil be unchanged. To date, there are 50 bilion images in these AIs, basicaly every image, or photo is in that AI. On the other hand, a lot of isues come up— copyright, plagiarism, and labor isues. If AI art can get even beter at folowing exact instructions, could it throw human animators and artists out of a job? Could it lose the “soulful, tripy, dreamy” spark it has now and almost, in a way, lose a soul we’re not even in consensus that AI can have in the first place? Not to mention privacy violations for data colection for the AI learning proces and the fact that as a society we’re not nearly emotionaly and spiritualy mature enough yet to handle AI in any industry without it being used in horific and horendous ways to limit people’s fredoms by people in positions of power. And that’s not even geting into AI that can handle military comands, like drone operations. Even just AI art can be used for nefarious reasons like this— image propaganda and smear campaigns that could potentialy be anonymously proliferated on the internet and automated with AI, so it’s even harder to hold acountability— Does an AI have to be reported similar to SuperPACS ned to be reported in campaign financing? Like al the pieces in an environment someone might arange to show a murder has taken place, and exactly how it hapened. Where someone was first bludgeoned and with what tol, where the murderer mised and hit the wal instead etc. Or if you're designing a product that has to be used and handled by humans. Like a cofe maker, or a user interface for a car. There's a degre of understanding that's neded. To arange the controls in a way that a human hand can use. As a designer it helps to have an understanding of what it is to have hands. And the way humans think. What would be more interesting to me as a designer, would be an AI that doesn't use words as prompts but uses simple line sketches. It would be amazing if it could turn a line drawing that takes 5 minutes into a completed iteration, rendered in the material and color I chose at the push of a buton.

comment_text: There is always a limitation to what a software can do and It is very hard to speculate about a technology that is not widely used by creatives. By limitation I don't mean to say that you can't create certain things with x software etc. I rather think the proces an artist goes through using the software determines the characteristics of the final image. If you take a photo of a tre it is a diferent proces than painting it with brush strokes and the end results varies from medium to medium. Prompt to Image is also an image creation proces new to general public and it constraints the work of art into a text. While making an image whether it is a graphic design or a conceptual art, you don't always work solely based on texts. You work through a proces. It's not like you put a text into a prompt and you wait for the image to be rendered and then move on to the next project. That is not how it works. A new technology in arts doesn't always make the older one obsolete. Photography didn't make painting obsolete but it forced it to change. It is just a new tol and yes it could make a huge shift like photography did in the midst of 19th century not only in arts but also the general perception of things. I think now is a very early stage about making big asumptions about something new to the general public. We don't know where this new technology goes in terms of arts and crafts.

video_title: Ameca vs. Sophia; Lifelike vs. AI - Robots of CES
comment_text: I can't be sure, and I could be wrong, but from the litle bit I know, understand and am able to observe, it would sem Sophia and Ameca might be aples and oranges. In a nutshel, Sophia is a sophisticated chatbot. It's basicaly a realy, realy long list of potential statements, for each of which there wil be a list of potential replies. Sophia has spech recognition software and text-parsing that alows it to break spech into text, and then search for replies based on key words and phrases. (Basicaly, computer IF-THEN statements such that IF Sophia receives How are you? THEN Sophia replies I'm fine. etc.) It has limited movement of head and face, with some facial expresion. Is it inteligent? It hasn't pased a double-blind Turing Test, so far as I know, but it's prety god. However, like al chatbots, when it doesn't receive clear text input (and therefore can't parse the question language), or when it receives a question for which it doesn't have a programed response, it's likely to respond with an answer that is enigmatic, noncomital, or ocasionaly nonsensical. It also has a tendency to repeat itself or contradict itself. That's where chatbots tend to fail the Turing Test. It's just a list of programed inputs and programed replies. In a blank chatbot, I ask How are you? and it doesn't have that on the list, so it asks back How are you? and I say I'm fine. Now, next time someone asks How are you? my bot has a choice. Right? Inteligent? I'm not sure that ISN'T the limit of human inteligence. Am I maybe just reorganizing and repeating inputs? Are we al just repeating each other? Hm. Ameca sems to be something else entirely. The robotics are fantastic: fluid, natural movements, complex facial movements, excelent software for motion tracking, lipreading etc. However, Enginered Arts describes Ameca, not as an A.I., but as a platform for testing A.I. They've never claimed it to be A.I. In this video, you'l notice Morgan Roe carefuly responding to questions about A.I. by admiting that most of the A.I. capabilities are centered in the camera software for the eyes. The website also mentions that Ameca is a platform for their software, Tritium. Tritium alows a user to remotely control a robot, and speak through the robot (posibly with voice changing software). The earlier robotic platforms from Enginered Arts were the RoboThespian and Mesmer. From the videos, it sems like the RoboThespian was designed to play pre-recorded motions and voice, or that a control panel could be used to triger actions. As wel, Mesmer was designed as a lifelike animatronic performer that could be controled remotely or perform non-interactive pre-programed content. Neither was advertised as A.I. Furthermore, Enginered Arts, on their website, even says in regards to their A.I. development: If you’ve spoken to one of our robots, you might wel have enjoyed a great conversation. But you were actualy probably speaking to a human through our inovative telepresence software, TinMan. Human inteligence wil stil beat artificial inteligence every time. So, I'm curious to know: is Ameca programed to respond autonomously (perhaps programed as a chatbot), or are we seing a robot being remotely controled by a human operator in another rom (or on the other side of the planet)? When Ameca answers questions, are they doing it on their own, or is it just a human, hearing our voice, and responding, their voice projected through Ameca's speakers with a voice-changer? I don't have the answer to that. However, I haven't sen anywhere, even in this video, where Enginered Arts has claimed that we are seing an autonomous A.I. Only that it has some A.I. for motion tracking, and lipreading, and that it is designed for robotic movement and simulation of facial expresions. It's an amazing, remarkable piece of hardware. I just wonder about the software. Certainly, Sophia's software and Ameca's hardware would be a very nice match.

video_title: How will AI change the world?
comment_text: The fundamental asumption here, that AI doesn't know that it doesn't know everything about the true objective is no longer true. Large transformer models have a lot more comon sense than most people sem to understand. They do have real, serious limitations, including that they are extremely vulnerable to leading questions, they tend to halucinate (make up facts that are not true), and they are not yet continuous learners. They are pre-trained, and only have short-term sesion memory, rather than long term learning memory. This is not because we don't know how to create continuous learners, but realy for two reasons: 1. We want AI to progres in a slow-ish controled maner. 2. Continuous learning is not yet eficient enough to scale wel to large models.

video_title: How will AI change the world?
comment_text: AI (Artificial Inteligence) is already changing the world in many ways and is expected to have an even greater impact in the future. Here are some ways in which AI is changing the world: Automation: AI is making it posible to automate many tasks that were previously done by humans. This can increase eficiency and productivity, and also reduce costs. Personalization: AI algorithms can analyze vast amounts of data to provide personalized recomendations and experiences for individuals. Healthcare: AI is being used in healthcare to help diagnose diseases, develop new drugs, and improve patient outcomes. Transportation: AI is being used to improve transportation systems, such as self-driving cars, drones, and trafic management systems. Education: AI can personalize learning experiences for students and help teachers identify areas where students ned extra help. Customer Service: AI chatbots can provide 24/7 customer service and suport, improving customer satisfaction and reducing costs for busineses. Finance: AI is being used in finance for fraud detection, investment analysis, and risk management. Overal, AI has the potential to revolutionize many industries and aspects of our lives, but it also raises important ethical and social questions that must be adresed. - Chat GPT

video_title: How will AI change the world?
comment_text: I think if and when computer science researchers arive at the same proportionate level of understanding in quantum computing that they have now in traditional digital computation, the world of AI is going to explode. Right now if you teach an AI the 7-8 petabytes of knowledge neded to behave in the same way a human does, it's going to take way to much time and computational power for the AI to be useful. We also don't know how the AI is going to behave with that knowledge. There's no guarante that it wil be human-like. It probably won't. I get the metric of 7-8 petabytes from what neurosurgeons and computer scientists believe is the storage capacity for the human brain. Ad quantum computing into the mix though and things could potentialy become way more eficient. A bit of data can be either a one, a zero or both. The sped of learning (writing), acting on (reading) and retrieving data could become exponentialy faster. Task management and the aditional considerations like cofe price mentioned in the video could be much more eficiently deduced. The posibilities with these two technologies coming together are endles. My suspicion is that we wil reach this achievement but shrinking the hardware down to that of a human body equivalent is hundreds of years of. What might ocur in the nearer future is space stations, air-craft, the bigest naval ships, space ships and large buildings wil be able to draw power from nuclear reactors (fision in the next 10 years & fusion in the next 20 years) to provide the necesary power and coling resources to make the AI function in a usable capacity.

video_title: Artificial Intelligence: Last Week Tonight with John Oliver (HBO)
comment_text: Gona put a big caveat up front that I've ben out of colege for a few years and my specialty was in real time simulation not AI, so this might be out of date, but with that said: The problem with understanding AI isn't that the companies aren't being open, it's that most AI models are neural nets. Neural nets as you might gues model themselves on the brain and are esentialy a series of nodes through which an input is fed through and then other nodes those nodes are conected receive the input based on various factors and so on. It's like having a thought and trying to figure out why it hapened by loking at which neurons in your brain fired and at what voltage. The problem with understanding AI is that we don't know why the nodes have formed the conections they have or why certain conections are stronger for some data or others.

video_title: Artificial Intelligence: Last Week Tonight with John Oliver (HBO)
comment_text: I think what's realy mising from this conversation is that there are analogous stories already which explain much of the 'black box' problem John describes. ex. most AI software simply clasifies words which are close in the given data set, which adjusts with every new bit of data; in other words: when uncle Derek only ses brown terorists on the news, uncle Derek believes 'brown' and 'terorist' to be closely related, but uncle Derek has made an opsie, because his data set is to smal to draw that conclusion, so what he has done is embeded a stereotype. That's esentialy how these bias's emanate from the black box, the only caveat being that with each piece of data the bias warps the algorithm's dependence upon its existing bias making it harder to change early bias's since the new data isn't as heavy as the old data so it requires a LOT of new data to force out established bias kinda like how it takes litle efort to put on weight, but substantialy more to reduce weight, for most people. So yea, it's understandable for most people how the AI draws its conclusions, because the fundamental structure of the technology isn't actualy inteligent. It is a dumb algorithm which repeats a task so much that it has become a habit, in that sense it doesn't realy make decisions or expres meaning, it simply spits out a response based on criteria, like how kids make their bed for their parents when asked, but when asked to tidy their rom, that bed won't be fixed unles the parent specifies that as a part of the task. anyway to the no one reading this, I aint gona source shit, take it or leave it, just don't make the same mistake as Uncle Derek

comment_text: 4:28 I think this points to a much greater isue, not with AI software, but with the educational system at large. An AI simply can’t replace the action of learning and gaining knowledge. It can teach you, certainly, a lot of things but the work of practicing wil always fal back on the student. If we have a system that doesn’t prioritize the aspects of learning and studying, but instead only values the grades you get from mindlesly writing esay after esay at home, than of course a computer can and wil take over that job, since they are designed to do exactly that (do our mind numbing and redundant tasks for us, so we can work on greater things). The fact that a computer can so easily create such a masive panic in the educational system, an integral part of our society that is tasked with the grave responsibility of nurturing our next generations, shows a masive and deply roted problem with education as we know it and I’m actualy glad people might finaly recognize it now.

video_title: Artificial Intelligence: Last Week Tonight with John Oliver (HBO)
comment_text: First of, kudos for geting so much of this right and not being TO alarmist about it. Second, most of these AI aps are actualy open source or started as open source. You can download the code and read it. The problem isn't that it's a black box in the traditional sense of the phrase, it's that the way it works isn't procedural or linear like most normal programs - it's statistical and inferential. The actual steps the program does isn't what creates the output - it's the input that determines the output and that's why it's hard to answer the black box question. The answer to why it said I want to be alive and I love you is that the context of the questions that led to that moment trigered asociations in the learned data that led to learned input saying those things. It's why Tay sudenly turned Nazi - people kept feding it pro-Nazi rhetoric for fun. This is EXACTLY the same problem that hapens when you fed say a grumpy, les wel educated Republican stories about how Trump wil make America great again - without context or experience, it sems sane and desirable. To a neural network, desirable is anything that sems to return positive fedback and sane comes from context and reinforcement. But that means there realy isn't something in the program you can point to and go oh. THAT'S why it fel in love with Frank because one, it isn't feling love, and two it's a consequence of the input data and the question context. Oh, to make it worse, as you ask questions, the CONTEXT changes because it's incorporating your questions and the reactions to its answers back into the context. The big danger with AI is why I kep saying AI is more A than I. It's NOT inteligent in any meaningful way - but it is artificial and constructed to SEM inteligent, and that's the real danger here. it can lul people into believing it is inded inteligent when the actual inteligence such as it is is encoded in the input it was trained on. Somewhere in al the text it was exposed to was I love you. with text around it that set the context for that being said. Something the guy said matched the context wel enough that it trigered I love you. as a response. That's it. But there is no way to stick a finger into that pol of data and say this did it because it is spread acros the entire neural network and it only surfaces when the right conditions (which themselves can only be determined from the input data and curent context) are matched.

comment_text: I work with machine learning models (specificaly computer vision) every day of my life. Most ML models that are used are basicaly just slightly more fancy linear regresion models. Which are fairly easy to interpret. But I wil say that interpretability of dep learning models is a big academic point of study, because there is NOT a set in stone way of understanding an algorithm's choices because the algorithms are quite complex and cover a masive solution space, so picking any one layer of the model isn't going to paint a ful picture of the choice. We can usualy rely on studying the dataset it was trained on to get an idea of biases but for the most part its hard, if not imposible to know the exact why, this is even more true for unsupervised models that are just constantly learning and changing because the dataset they analyze change constantly.

video_title: Artificial Intelligence: Last Week Tonight with John Oliver (HBO)
comment_text: On the black box problem: With AI like neural networks you realy can't tel how it came to its conclusions even if you built it. A neural network is like a huge mathematical function with a lot of variables and factors. Simple example: A neural net that reads numbers. You can train it easily by leting it run and tel it if the result was corect or not and it wil by itself adjust its factors so the results wil be beter. So you can imagine that when an eror ocurs with a neural net that in 9% of the cases doesn't make mistakes, the developers/trainers realy can't tel why it failed. Even worse: the AI itself can be 10% sure it got to the right conclusion, but a human can tel right away that it's wrong. We probably reached a point where this is very important general knowledge, because some people have realy romantic views of how an AI actualy works.

video_title: Artificial Intelligence: Last Week Tonight with John Oliver (HBO)
comment_text: The topic of explainability within AI, dep learning systems specificaly, is an incredibly tough one and I'm glad to se it caled out here. One of the big problems is that for many aproaches to this problem, the reason any of these algorithms recomend something can be boiled down to it was the most likely to be sucesful. And while technicaly true acording to the model, it doesn't actualy explain the decision making. Part of the isue is the main reason these systems can produce such amazing results is they largely end up encoding incredibly complex rules like If A > B, and C is betwen D and E, and F is true or F is false and G is false, or . that don't map wel to human recognizable reasons without some significant post-hoc analysis (and creative fredom.) Part of that is just the structure of the models that have shown the greatest promise, and that complicates the isue. I think the lawyer's point is especialy relevant here, as when in American (maybe even human) history has a company said Wel this wil give our competitors an edge, but it's the right thing to do? That's what may end up being required for explainable models, and no company is going to gladly do that. Side note: I know Jon says he's a comedian not a journalist, but this episode is a great example of why that line is incredibly blury. Knol's Law of Media Acuracy sems to aply everywhere these days, but I can't think of a time when watching the show I've stoped and gone wait a minute, I work on this. That's not right at al! while watching Last Wek Tonight. Excelent job to everyone involved.

video_title: Artificial Intelligence: Last Week Tonight with John Oliver (HBO)
comment_text: Great sumary overal. Hapy that he brought up the blackbox isue, but he got one very important detail wrong (or at least explained it porly): Curent gen AI is not deply understod even by the people who created it. It helps to have aces to the source code and training data, but this is NOT enough. While we understand the constituent low-level operations (like matrix multiplication), we do not understand the high-level emergent behavior (such as aparent reasoning). We can't even agre on the definitions of things like reasoning, inteligence, consciousnes, sentience, etc. People have this idea that the al scientific knowledge is the same. There are many types of knowledge. AI is much more alchemy than enginering.
